Well, it's a really well made game and I really don't like it because it foregoes a TON of modern conveniences for the sake of "realism". I want instant fast travel, instant looting that doesn't even need a button press, I want to be able to store 5 alive deer in my pocket, I want to be able to compare gun stats easily when I find one on the ground. To me the whole thing feels like a painfully sluggish horse riding simulator with a thousand buttons worth of controls (I punched my horse an I'm not proud of it). Also I accidentally ran over a dumb dog and now I'm wanted in 7 countries. I... man. Everybody says it's a great game, but I'm actually having so little fun.

I tried the game again, got into a bunch of encounters I hated, accidentally killed a man with a horse and got stuck on an oil wagon mission. Sigh...

I am very sad to say this, but Rockstar doesn't care about this game. The amount of detail put in Story is amazing, better than any game made in 2018 or maybe even today. But Online is a different story. It is a complete piece of garbage. Rockstar doesn't care whatsoever. There have been 0 new updates that actually bring something new to the game for around a year. Online is a simple cash grab. It was never meant to last as an actual game to be fun; all Rockstar cares about is money. If you are contemplating about buying Red Dead Online standalone after buying GTA, do not. This game is £20, which could be spent on something actually useful. You cannot own properties; you can own around 2 actual businesses, and only one of them has a building (barely customisable). The game crashes randomly for no reason. The Online mode is unplayable in its current state. Rockstar doesn't give a **** about it. They haven't bothered to fix it. The only reason Red Dead Online is still running is because Rockstar is selling Gold Bars. As soon as people stop buying Gold Bars, this game will shut down. I'm very sad to see what it could have been and what it is right now. RDRO should be put in a Beta state; you cannot release a game like this. You could have increased the map size, added Mexico, and made it so you could buy houses and shops. It could have been infinitely better. This isn't even a fraction of what it could have been. All Rockstar does is add 1 limited clothing item every month and call it a day. They add bonuses every month, but this month, it didn't even work for the first few days. Can you believe that? All they do is click a button to add double pay for a single role, but they couldn't even do that?! This is a terrible look for Rockstar. Something has to happen with this game because this won't be a good look for GTA 6 Online, either. But who cares, every online made by Rockstar is a simple cash grab. Here is the part I don't understand. Rockstar wants money, so if RDRO were updated, that would surely bring more players and make you more money. The fact that this game won Labour of Love amazes me. The fact that this game won any award whatsoever is crazy. Sorry for my little rant. Rockstar is clearly behaving like Dutch at this point. Except that Dutch has a plan, Rockstar doesn't.

Red Dead Redemption 2: A Masterpiece of Interactive Storytelling and Immersive Gameplay

Red Dead Redemption 2 isn't just a game; it's an immersive journey into the heart of the American Wild West, a meticulously crafted masterpiece that sets a new standard for open-world gaming experiences. From its breathtaking landscapes to its deeply engaging narrative, every aspect of this game is a testament to Rockstar Games' unparalleled dedication to their craft.

Let's start with the world itself. The sheer scale and detail of the world Rockstar has created are nothing short of astounding. From the snow-capped mountains of the Grizzlies to the swamps of Lemoyne, every inch of the map feels alive and teeming with activity. Whether you're riding through the heartland of New Hanover or navigating the bustling streets of Saint Denis, there's always something new and exciting to discover.

But what truly sets Red Dead Redemption 2 apart is its storytelling. At its core, this is a tale of redemption, loyalty, and the struggle to survive in a rapidly changing world. The game puts you in the boots of Arthur Morgan, a rugged outlaw and member of the Van der Linde gang, as he grapples with his own morality and the looming specter of his past. As you journey across the American frontier, you'll encounter a colorful cast of characters, each with their own hopes, dreams, and demons to confront.

The writing in Red Dead Redemption 2 is nothing short of phenomenal. Every conversation, every mission, every random encounter feels like it was lifted straight from the pages of a classic Western novel. The dialogue crackles with authenticity, drawing you deeper into the world and the lives of its inhabitants. And the performances from the voice cast, particularly Roger Clark as Arthur Morgan, are simply breathtaking, bringing each character to life in vivid detail.

Of course, a great story is nothing without great gameplay to back it up, and Red Dead Redemption 2 delivers in spades. Whether you're engaging in intense shootouts with rival gangs, hunting legendary animals in the wilderness, or simply sitting around the campfire swapping stories with your fellow outlaws, every moment feels like a natural extension of the world and the characters that inhabit it.

And then there's the attention to detail. From the way Arthur's beard grows over time to the realistic physics of horseback riding, every aspect of Red Dead Redemption 2 has been painstakingly crafted to create the most immersive experience possible. The level of realism is staggering, making you feel like you've truly stepped back in time to the dying days of the Wild West.

But perhaps what is most impressive about Red Dead Redemption 2 is its ability to evoke a wide range of emotions. One moment you'll find yourself laughing at the antics of your fellow gang members, and the next you'll be on the edge of your seat as you race against the clock to pull off a daring heist. And then there are the quieter moments, the moments of reflection and introspection, where you'll find yourself pondering the nature of morality and the choices we make in life.

In conclusion, Red Dead Redemption 2 is not just a game; it's a work of art. It's a testament to the power of storytelling in video games, and a shining example of what can be achieved when a team of talented developers pour their hearts and souls into their craft. If you're a fan of open-world games, Westerns, or just great storytelling in general, do yourself a favor and saddle up for the ride of a lifetime with Red Dead Redemption 2. You won't regret it.

Honestly, I've only so far read about the end of Arthur Morgan but I feel it's another example of unnecessary character murder that plaques modern interactive media and movies... It's as if it was somehow more realistic and enjoyable to conclude the story in which the protagonist ends up dead for whatever reason and it just plainly sucks in my opinion. 

Otherwise a fantastic game gets ruined by a unnecessary dramatic finale for the character and leaves a sour taste on mouth as if real world consequences were so fun why would we engage into escapism in the video games in the first place. Maybe the justification for making such story is that "times were changing", "Arthur was a bad man running out of time", or "Tuberculosis claimed good and bad alike those days"... or something along the line but honestly I'm personally sick and tired of having all the interesting characters get killed for no merit to the actual story except "well, the story has to end sometime", it doesn't mean the character would live forever if they had a happy ending but rather I honestly would personally rather see good endings to good stories instead of this "world is murky pond of eventuality that everyone has to face one day". 

I doubt anyone thinks such endings are deep or meaningful as it's literally happening to everyone eventually and it isn't even pleasing as the character we've cherished and enjoyed following the exploits, developments, interactions with characters and etc. suddenly kicks the bucket and we are just left with the naive ending of "and then they died, end of story".
It's pathetic way to end a story of otherwise good character in a good story with such enjoyable vistas and other details with thousands of hours behind and for this reason I will not recommend this game for anyone.

Red Dead Redemption 2 is a tour de force of game development. If you haven't yet played it, and you enjoy an immersive open world, do yourself a favor and play it. If you appreciate slower paced open world RPGs like Fallout, you will love Red Dead 2.

The attention to detail is second to none. Carrying bodies leaves blood on your shoulder. Coyotes chase after rabbits. Every NPC interacts with the environment, whether it's hammering nails, or doing farm work, or chatting with each other. You can greet every rider you pass, or insult them and pick a fight. The world feels truly alive in a way that I've never experienced in another game.

RDR2 isn't perfect. It's very slow paced at times. When you skin an animal, it takes 5-10 seconds, which I know is aggravating for some players. The controls can feel clunky, both on and off your horse—although the animations are excellent, and the game does the very best it can to make all of your movements and your horse's movements look totally natural.

 It has a number of mechanics that can feel half-done at times, but the silver lining is that you only have to engage in these features if you want to. If you never clean your gun, you probably won't notice any difference. It doesn't matter that much if you eat regularly, or keep your horse brushed, or if you contribute food and money to the gang's camp. But you can do all of these things, and the game does reward you, if only a little.

The story is very good, if occasionally feeling padded by a handful of detours to make the length of the game appropriate. The voice acting is top-notch, and it's matched by great animation in and out of cutscenes.

There is also just SO much content, and this is coming from someone who hasn't touched the Online stuff. There's dozens of side missions and activities, random interactions, and points of interest to find. I'm on like my 4th playthrough with 500+ hours and I'm still finding things I've never come across before. I can just get lost in this game like no other. I load the game up with the intention of hunting down a particular animal for the compendium, or completing a certain mission, and then save and quit an hour later and realize I did nothing but wander. 

There's a reason Rockstar games are 2 or 3 times a decade—it's worth the wait. I can't recommend Red Dead Redemption 2 enough. It's just a masterpiece in every sense of the word.

If you have no issues with the DRM protection/install/turning off windows security which the game basically requires, it is still - several years later - the most beautiful video game with an amazing cast and brilliant story writing. A full play through will take well over 100 hours if you do some side missions, and several hundred if you do all the side missions.

Entering the world of Red Dead Redemption was like stepping into the untamed frontier, where Arthur's story unfolded with depth and intrigue. The landscapes were more than just scenery; they were vast and stunning, inviting exploration at every turn. Hunting and fishing weren't just activities, they were immersive experiences that connected me to the wilderness and the atmosphere.  Every encounter felt meaningful, every decision impactful. The order in which to take some missions were a bit tricky though. So keep an eye on that. Having initially enjoyed it on PS4, the urge to relive the adventure led me to get it again for PC, where the enhanced graphics and smoother performance added a new layer of immersion.

I can't run this game offline. I have *really* bad issues with latency where I am and travel, so I launch in Offline mode a lot. This game has a pop up that says "I do not own the game, offline data can be loaded".

I heard many good this about this game, and I enjoyed the 3 hours I put in before this issue. But if I cannot play it offline, I can't really say I'm pleased with this game.

I found this game so insanely boring. The story (which was pretty interesting to be fair) was sooooo insanely long and every single mission I played was just 90% walking around following someone or bringing someone somewhere, then 10% insta-killing bad guys in 5 seconds because the game's difficulty is a joke. 

There's a button to mount your horse, a button to pet your horse, a button to talk to your horse, a button to store cargo on your horse, a button to play chess with your horse, and a button to shoot it in the head and then walk 50 miles to the nearest stable to get a new one since you can't even ride your allies horses. There should be a button to make this game more like GTA V.

I'm not going to call it perfect, but it is reaaaally close. Combat is smooth as butter, character customization is top-tier, and the story is compelling. It is Witcher 3 in the west for top-tier gameplay experience. My only complaint is the dissonance between gameplay and cutscenes for Arthur. I get that there is a "canon" version of him, but I feel like New Vegas' karma system was better in this regard.

I waited so long to acquire this on a good sale. I'm sure I've missed a few but finally saw this on sale and can't say I'm upset for waiting. I use DSR to upscale my 3440x1440 to 5160x2160 then DLSS on Performance and all other settings on Ultra. I fine tune advanced settings, such as Motion Blur off. I consistently pull a locked 120fps to match my monitor hz rate with Vsync and Gsync enabled using a 4080 Founders. It's matches the quality of modern releases with a superior story line and in game elements. This is absolutely I game I will end up with no less than 100 hours of enjoyment. For $34 bucks (ultimate edition) I think that is a fine purchase indeed.

This is one of the most memorable games I've ever played. I really mean it. I usually don't find cowboy themes interesting. However, this story absolutely blew my mind away. The characters are incredibly engaging and relatable. Each person in the story added an element and personality to an entertaining gang of early 20th century wild west buccaneers. Although there is a very obvious main antagonist, the writing is done so well that it makes him seem like much more than a driving force of selfish and narcissistic goals. In the end its great characters that create an unforgettable story. 

The overall gameplay mechanics are really enjoyable, and I liked that I had the option of progressing through the game at my own pace. The amount of freedom it gives you is great way of achieving this. The reputation system implements an awesome feedback loop that allows the players' decisions to feel like actual meaningful decisions. On top of this, the graphics are so hyper-realistic, and every object in the game is rendered so well. I really enjoyed this aesthetic choice because it created an environment that made the characters feel more real and emotionally connected. Red Dead Redemption 2 plays like a film festival masterpiece.

After 3 years I am rewriting my review as some past events have changed this game's situation quite a bit.

[h1]RDR2[/h1]
Regarding the RDR2 base game, as in, the Story Mode, nothing has changed and it's still a great game that is on its own enough reason to pay the full price tag. The story is very compelling and generally extremely polished, as befits Rockstar's fame for making amazing singleplayer experiences. The world is immersive and very detailed, and is certainly one of the game's greatest highlights. It's also fairly lengthy, with a narrative that may take around 60 hours to complete and does not get boring at all.

[strike]There has also been talk of a RDR remake recently, as some trademarking documents have come up, so we have that to look forward to. If it's real, of course.[/strike] Nevermind it was a fucking Switch port :skull:

[h1]RDO[/h1]
The meat of this review, however, is RDO. It's no exaggeration to call it a dead game. Rockstar is also famous for its horrific work on GTAO, and RDO just takes it to the next level. While GTAO is often complained about because of things like being too grindy, and the fact that the prices for newer content are unbalanced when compared to the original set of content due to a lack of future planning; RDO just cranks it to 11. Instead of hearing the community and making the game less grindy, they simply made [b]everything[/b] expensive. However, you soon come to the realization that there isn't really anything to sink your money into to begin with.

The main problem here is the [b]lack of content[/b]. Rockstar has officially, as of 2021, abandoned RDO. The game no longer receives major content updates and lots of bugs that have been known about for a long time, like the Blackwater Stable glitch, are still in the game. You can grind mindlessly for about a month to get yourself the basics, like good weapons, a good horse, some bling, etc... only to come to the realization that [b]that's it[/b]. You literally have nothing else left to do. The story is super short, if you're generous enough to say it actually exists; the roles are extremely repetitive and boring, and so are any sort of missions like the Blood Money and Telegram content.

This is all made even worse by the unfixed, progress breaking glitches, and the overwhelming amount of cheaters that plague the game.

In a nutshell, RDO has the amazing base that RDR2 is, and it certainly uses its world, but it doesn't do a good job of being fun, neither does Rockstar care to ever change that in the future.

You feel like a real cowboy. You live every little moment of Arthur's life and it's never dull. Shooting the shite out of bandits and feds, sneaky burglary, living off the land, quiet moments of reflection. Even how Arthur walks makes you feel powerful. The story is surprisingly subversive - you love every character, but cowboys aren't so noble after all. My favorite part about Arthur, besides his manner of speaking, is his journal - he has a steady hand and keen eye and he uses it to capture the wild America that we've lost with drawings and writings of his capers.

10/10 Game, played it on Xbox at release and am still playing it and finding new things 6 years later. If you haven't played this game, you are doing yourself a disservice. 

This game is so incredibly detailed you can wander off in the woods and find something new and cool. There are so many different interactions you can have, and the immersion is so good. The characters and incredibly well written, and the gameplay is so much fum.

However, the game isn't perfect. Some sections of the game are tedious, badly designed, and a lot of features do basically nothing. The horse movement is not the greatest at times, and your own movement isn't the greatest sometimes. This game is, in my opinion, something you enjoy most if you slow down and just look at everything. Racing through this game will mean you miss 90% of cool stuff this game has to offer. Definitely recommend playing this game if you haven't, or go for another play-through if you have. I hope you enjoy this game as much as I have, and I hope you bite the bullet and bite this wonderful game. Thank you, have a wonderful day.

Hosea, Dutch, and Arthur
A young Arthur (right) with Hosea Matthews and Dutch van der Linde.

Arthur Morgan was born circa 1863[1] to Beatrice and Lyle Morgan in the northern United States.[2] As a child, his mother died of unknown causes, while his father was a petty criminal and outlaw. In 1874, when Arthur was 11 years old, his father was arrested for larceny. Morgan later witnessed his death and, despite a strained relationship with him, still donned his hat and kept a picture of him.[3][4]

Around 1877, Arthur was found as a 'wild delinquent' and picked up off the streets by Dutch van der Linde and Hosea Matthews.[5] Viewing the pair as surrogate father figures, Arthur came to share Dutch's vision of a life lived free from the constraints of civilization and the rule of law. The pair taught him how to read, write, hunt, fight, shoot, and ride, becoming their first protégé as well as one of the founding members of the Van der Linde gang.

Arthur found a pet dog named Copper at some point whom he grew particularly close to and occasionally took baths with. Although Arthur had difficulty controlling him, he admired the dog's spirit. Copper later passed away and Arthur kept a picture of him on his wagon. He also later acquired a mare named Boadicea whom he became fond of and she became his signature mount.

As a young adult, Arthur met a girl named Mary Gillis where the two fell deeply in love and even became engaged. He befriended her younger brother Jamie and taught him horseback-riding. However, Arthur's preference for a life of crime coupled with the prevalent disapproval of Mary's family, most strongly from her father ultimately caused their relationship to fall apart and the pair separated.

In 1884, Arthur was sent out fishing and pridefully returned with three beautiful bass. The gang celebrated with a big feast and toasted him all night long. The following week, Arthur and Dutch walked in the local market where it was revealed that he had simply purchased the bass from a fish monger, much to his embarrassment.[6]

In 1885, Arthur met a 12 year-old boy named John Marston who had been saved by Dutch from being lynched by a group of Illinois homesteaders. John was inducted into the gang and raised alongside Arthur with the pair growing as close as brothers. Dutch instilled the boys with his anarchist worldviews against a corrupt government and preached that revenge was a fool's game. Over the years, Arthur and John became regarded as Dutch's favorite 'sons'.

In 1887, Arthur participated in the gang's first major bank robbery alongside Dutch and Hosea. At 2 o'clock, the trio burst into the banking house of Lee and Hoyt and managed to make off with $5000 in gold. After the robbery, they lingered in town, going to hovels, shanties, and orphanages handing out money, envisioning themselves as 'Robin Hood' figures.[7] It was following this event where Arthur became a wanted man.

Some years later, Arthur met and slept with a 19 year-old waitress named Eliza, resulting in her becoming pregnant with their son, Isaac. Although Eliza knew of Arthur's lifestyle, she accepted whatever support he offered to her and their son. Arthur, not wanting to promise anything he couldn't keep, said that he would do right by them. He would periodically visit Eliza and Isaac every few months and stay with them for days at a time. Arthur remembered fondly of Isaac as a 'good kid'.

Tragically one day, however, Arthur arrived at their home and saw two crosses outside. He knew immediately that they were both dead, and later learned that they had been shot and killed by robbers, all for ten dollars.[8] This traumatic incident hardened Arthur as a result as he never truly coped with the pain and gave him the understanding to not live the life of an outlaw and expect good things to happen to him.

In 1894, a prostitute named Abigail Roberts joined the Van der Linde Gang. At some point, she fell in love with John Marston and became pregnant with their son named Jack. Arthur became a surrogate uncle figure towards him growing up. John however refused to accept responsibility over the boy and soon left the gang. Around a year later, John returned, while Dutch and the majority of the gang welcomed him back with open arms, Arthur felt betrayed by his actions and a rift was formed between the two which steadily grew over the years.

By 1898, the gang had found itself in Montana. During their stay, Hosea caught several large salmon during a fishing trip and planned to prepare a feast for the whole camp. However, the feast was cut short when Copper found and ate the fish, passing away soon after.[9] After a fire, in which Arthur's old journal was lost, and some trouble up north, the gang traveled south and east, taking a slow and tortuous trail down through the Northern Grizzlies to throw off anyone tracking them. They then spent several months in the wilderness. During the winter, they stuck mostly to the western foothills of the mountain.

While traversing the Grizzlies, several new members were picked up and brought into the gang. A young teenager, Lenny Summers, and a drifting outlaw, Charles Smith. Arthur had generally fair opinions of the pair, eventually forming close bonds with the two. Later on, the gang came across Jenny Kirk, a young woman abandoned by the roadside. The most recent member inducted into the gang was Micah Bell, a hot-headed career outlaw who saved Dutch's life in a shootout. Although Dutch found a liking to Micah, Arthur openly disliked him for his tendencies.

By the spring of 1899, the gang had arrived in West Elizabeth and decided to hide in plain sight just outside Blackwater, a town undergoing the process of industrialization. The gang began to scope out many leads, including Arthur and Hosea, who were planning a hefty real estate scam. Despite this, Dutch was also planning something big. Supported by Micah, Dutch began working on plans to rob a ferry laden with riches coming to town. Hosea and Arthur were reluctant despite Dutch's beliefs. His plan was to carry out the heist then flee west, possibly into New Austin. Then, after Arthur and Hosea carried out their scam, they would join the gang the following day.

Unfortunately, the ferry heist did not go as expected. At some point during the robbery, the gang was ambushed by the Pinkertons, causing a massive firefight known as the Blackwater Massacre. Arthur and Hosea arrived late, and by then, the gang was barely holding on.[10] Several gang members were killed or seriously injured, and they fled the area in an "almighty scramble," north into the mountains in hopes of avoiding the law. Arthur suspected that the heist might have been a set up.

RDR2 is the first and only game I bought twice on different platforms (PS4 Pro and PC), and undoubtedly the singleplayer content I played for the most hours (over 300 hours without touching the multiplayer). This is because I love its open world and how it is built, a spectacular Wild West brought to light by the developers, where losing yourself just exploring nature is a real pleasure. 

Story, characters, side activities and gameplay are solid as always when you consider this is a Rockstar game, even if their strict and cinematic bound mission structure could be innovated a bit. The real gem is the main character, Arthur Morgan, probably my favorite videogame protagonist of all time. 

Technically everything is high tier, light simulation and music score on top of all. Character models maybe are not up to today's standards anymore, as this is a 2018/19 game, but everything else shines for attention to detail and simulation realism. To this day I think this is the best open world ever created, a game I highly recommend to everyone without reservation. 9/10!

I Absolutely love the Red Dead Redemption story line! Rockstar Games continues to exceed expectations every time they release a game. Many memorable characters and moments that prove how thought out the writing is. The main story includes 100+ missions. This is a top tier open world game that doesn't cut corners and really focuses on realism and the smallest of details. A goofy example of this is how your horses balls will actually shrivel up if it's in a cold environment. There's also a lot of really cool easter eggs and side missions that carry a completely different tone which helps shake things up and makes a lot of them a must see. It should be noted that at any time you can take a break from being a cowboy and take on the role of a hunter, fisherman, bounty hunter, gambler, plus more. Games like these will remind you that there are still passionate developers out there. That's why there are only a few games of this caliber every decade. Now we just need a RDR1 PC port!

Red Dead Redemption 2 is one of those games you will never forget. The game takes you away to the frontier and stalks you, and the people you learn to care about, as that frontier is slowly chipped away. The story and immersion of the game are its greatest strengths. However, that immersion comes at the cost of many game mechanics when compared to modern titles. The gun-play is rudimentary, the map and quick travel are prehistoric, the inventory and equipment management is clunky as !@$@. Sounds terrible? Well, that's the point. From the beautiful visuals, sounds, and survival elements you get a simple map, have to take the time to travel anywhere, hopefully on a horse, the guns simple for sure, and you feel like you're physically pulling out a can of baked beans to eat every time you open the inventory. Rock-star clearly created a game around the immersive nature of the game. At the price of your convenience, so enjoy. 

Achievement-wise the game is quiet systematic with a few miss-able achievements (bears!), for the most part you do need to be rather thorough, but as any achievement hunter will tell you this adds a whole new experience to the game as you find all those extra gems that Rockstar put in, their effort is on full display here and you will be grateful you took the time. That being said, WTH are Red Dead Online achievements... sigh... guess I need to do those too. Time to brush-up on my social skills. MVP 3 times... seriously.

Arthur Morgan and the Van der Linde gang are outlaws on the run. With federal agents and the best bounty hunters in the nation massing on their heels, the gang must rob, steal and fight their way across the rugged heartland of America in order to survive. As deepening internal divisions threaten to tear the gang apart, Arthur must make a choice between his own ideals and loyalty to the gang who raised him.

Now featuring additional Story Mode content and a fully-featured Photo Mode, Red Dead Redemption 2 also includes free access to the shared living world of Red Dead Online, where players take on an array of roles to carve their own unique path on the frontier as they track wanted criminals as a Bounty Hunter, create a business as a Trader, unearth exotic treasures as a Collector or run an underground distillery as a Moonshiner and much more.

With all new graphical and technical enhancements for deeper immersion, Red Dead Redemption 2 for PC takes full advantage of the power of the PC to bring every corner of this massive, rich and detailed world to life including increased draw distances; higher quality global illumination and ambient occlusion for improved day and night lighting; improved reflections and deeper, higher resolution shadows at all distances; tessellated tree textures and improved grass and fur textures for added realism in every plant and animal.

[h1] An absolute masterpiece [/h1]

One of the most emotionally compelling stories ever written. Great character development for both main and side characters. If you want to fully experience the development of Arthur Morgan, playing the side quests is a must. The story fully describes the social and political development of America and its people at the end of the "old west" period.

The game world is as immersive as it gets. Side character dialogues and arguments, npc provocations and mugging attempts, animal attacks, treasure hunters observing the mountains and waterfalls, wild horses roaming the plains.... The most detailed enviroment I've ever seen in a game, corpses rot and get eaten by scavanging animals, your beard and hair grows, you need to dress apropriatly to the weather conditons, I could go on forever... Hunting and fishing are a big part of the game and the mechanics are made exceptionaly well with countless species of animals and fish that act in just like in nature.
Combat is very realistic, brutal and satisfying with a lot of weapon options. 

The story mode is very long and will easily take you 80+ hours on a playthrough if you want to fully experience it.

As for the online mode, I played it solo focusing on trader and bounty hunter roles, it was very fun but once you get a good horse, weapons and max out your role ranks there is really not much left to do and you have nothing to spend your money on. Playing roles is a huge grind but I enjoyed it a lot.  Also when you reach 80+ rank there is not much to do. Ranking up doesn't take very long if you grind the roles and take advantage of seasonal rockstar bonuses. For me it was great for 50h but I have nothing left to do in online, had a lot more potential. 

As for optimization the game runs very smoothly and looks beautiful. You need rockstar laucher to play it which is a bit annoying but never caused any problems for me.

I am 257 hours in and what was an enjoyable game is spoiled by hackers. I get blown up every day. No known way to stop this so I log off.  The fun is gone. I expect a modern software development company to be able to stop this.

On the plus side I enjoyed the solo game lots before this trouble.

ROCKSTAR GAMES 10/10 Every time

"We can't change what's done, we can only move on."

- Arthur Morgan

===================================================================

What an absolute MASTERPIECE! This game is the result of good storytelling and good game mechanic combined. It doesn't matter if you haven't played the first RDR, because this is actually set before it as we're introduced to the Van der Linde gang in their "glorious" era, and the writing is magnificent. I dare say, Arthur Morgan is one of the most well-written video game characters of all time (so far). I love how Rockstar Games put a lot of effort to give details to the Game like if you hunt an animal but shoot at the body, the skin/pelt will have a lower quality because you "ruined" it. Also, trivial stuff like there's this bird species that can go extinct when you kill a certain number of them. They all make the Game more "alive".

When it comes to the game mechanic, RDR2 will give you an intuition to do some stuff out of curiosity (just like GTA), like trying to get on top of a train car while riding a horse or try to lasso our NPC friend when out of Camp area. This just proves that the game mechanic is so rich, that even if we can't do the stuff we're curious about it's still quite enough and satisfying. You have many types of gun to choose, you can hunt legendary animals, rob a stagecoach, and make a camp to cook or craft or sleep. The visual is so good that I couldn't help myself to take a screenshot or use photo mode in almost every corner of the RDR2 world. There's also an honor system (you can choose to be bad or good) that can actually affect how the people talk to you and even the outcome of some missions and cutscenes.

I, myself, am not actually a fan of Wild West theme.. But, boy oh boy, this Game sometimes made me want to do horse-riding and buy a revolver gun. I can't wait for GTA VI, the RDR remaster, or even better, RDR3 (here's hoping)!

===================================================================

This game is no doubt epic and with gorgeous visuals.  For me, it falls short in two areas.  First, the pace of the game is really slow.  I had so much fun playing the first RDR, but this one struggles to find a pacing that keeps me engaged.  You spend a ton of time just riding around your horse across the open world doing nothing but traveling from one destination to the next.

The second issue, with which I've been back and forth with Rockstar support many times and without adequate resolution, is that the game has an always-online requirement, even for the single player story mode.  I've tried everything they've offered to me, but the game absolutely refuses to start in offline mode.  If you're hoping to go on an airplane or a vacation where you have limited internet access, don't look here.  The game steadfastly refuses to start if you try and launch the game without a network connection.

Red Dead Redemption 2 may very well be one of the most in-depth simulations of life we've ever seen. It manages to do all the things survival games have been trying to do while making them interesting and not invasive. It gives players a real sense of playing their role through the honor system and the character skill progression by actions your character performs. And above all, in truest Rockstar fashion, it's one of the best stories in gaming, and Arthur Morgan quickly becomes an even more lovable character than I expected. RDR2's start is slow, measured, but as the layers begin to unfold and the scope of the game's sandbox is known, you see just how impressive it all really is. This is easily a top candidate for one of the greatest open world RPGs of all time.

You can feel the passion from beginning to end.

There are two modes, story and online mode.

Story mode's pacing is slow, similar to Death Stranding but includes more PVE, however you can feel when you play it is very refined. Feels like a movie that you are taking part in with extremely high level of detail. 

Needs good graphics card, a good monitor (i.e OLED) to fully enjoy the beautiful graphics.

Characterisation is extremely good, there were not a single awkward dialogue.

Lots of things to do, needs minimal brain power, its the kind of game where you play when you want to relax with after a busy day at work.

Can get boring if you do not like super long movies with slow pacing.

I care for the random strangers that exist in this game's world because the simulation of humanity is so vivid that it emotionally affects me in a way other games do not. I love this game so much. Let me make it clear that I do recommend this game to anyone who is interested in a slower-paced high production life-sim/open world action game. I have criticisms of this game, especially of the experience of playing through the main story compared to the incredible open world gameplay, but that's not the real problem with this game.

I can't play it offline because of the rockstar launcher requiring a constant internet connection to verify that you on your account are playing this game. "always online" DRM that no one likes, and no one wants except for stockholders who have "heard" that it cuts down on piracy so they force it on every AAA studio.

Boy oh boy,
mich hat es über 100 Stunden gekostet dieses Spiel zu beenden und ich bereue nichts.
Die Spielzeit bezieht sich nur auf den Story Modus, da der online Modus bei mir immer sofort abstürzte wenn ich versuchte ihn zu starten.
Wie dem auch sei. Ich hatte also vor über zehn Jahren Red Dead Redemption auf der PlayStation 3 gespielt und war daher sehr erfreut von RDR2 zu hören. Ich bin zwar erst spät auf den Zug aufgesprungen aber es hat sich gelohnt.
Wer RDR kennt und liebt, der kann jetzt aufhören zu lesen und sich das Spiel selbst zur gemühte führen.

Allen die jetzt noch immer hier sind sei gesagt, ihr solltet Western mögen, denn hier bekommt ihr jede Menge davon. Und auch jede Menge Entscheidungsmöglichkeiten. Wollt ihr der Gute, der Böse oder was dazwischen sein? Es liegt bei euch.
Zwischen Bankräuben und Frauen, spielt ihr den Ziehvater von John Marston, den Helden des ersten Spiels, Arthur Morgan. Wie es sich für einen Amerikanischen Cowboy gehört, mordet und schießt ihr euch durch die Geschichte des Wilden Westens und ab und zu verschlägt es euch vielleicht an den Pokertisch.

Zur Grafik:
Hier erhaltet ihr einen würdigen modernen Nachfolger. Überzeugend und nur mit moderner Hardware zu machen. Dennoch grafisch kein Fotorealismus. 

Zum Gameplay:
Wie von Rockstar gewöhnt grundsolide. Allerdings hat das Spiel ein massives Problem damit, euch eure Waffen zu lassen. Ständig wird die Ausrüstung gewechselt zu etwas, was das Spielt glaubt, sei angemessen. Mehr als nur einmal könntet ihr ein lieb gewonnenes Schießeisen einfach verlieren, wenn Rockstar mal wieder danach ist. Das ist mir als massiv störend aufgefallen und war besonders im letzten Drittel der Story (Epilog eingeschlossen) auffällig.

Müsst ihr wissen.
Definitely get the ultimate edition when on sale. Lovely game! Cannot wait to spend more time on it.

Red Dead Redemption 2, is an absolute visual masterpiece. The graphics are stunning, immersing players in a breathtaking open-world environment that truly brings the Old West to life. Beyond the eye-catching visuals, the game boasts a compelling narrative that captivates from start to finish. The storyline is not only great, but the ending is nothing short of epic, leaving players with a sense of awe and satisfaction. What sets Red Dead Redemption 2 apart is its replay value – a game worth playing many times over. The combination of outstanding graphics, an engaging story, and the potential for multiple playthroughs makes it a must-have in any gamer's library.

I played RDR1 on my old PS3 a few months prior to the release of this game in hopes of understanding the story better. Truthfully speaking it is not necessary, but I would still recommend playing it first for one reason alone; most likely, a vast majority of players will not like the simplicity of the gunplay/hunting/outfit system and just the world in general if they play it after playing RDR2. This won't be because these features are badly executed or anything along those lines, but instead because of the fact that you will probably be comparing both games in the back of your head, running the risk of becoming demotivated and eventually putting a stop to your RDR1 play-through. It would be a great shame in my opinion to not experience the first game as its story is a beautiful masterpiece that should be honoured by any proper RDR fan. 

I pre-ordered RDR2 and started on my PS4 in 2018 on its release date. I played until chapter 6 and left Arthur for 5 years until December 2023 where I finally came back to complete the story. If you're wondering why, I just got burnt out while doing every little thing in the game and therefore took a short break. Unfortunately during this time the story got spoiled for me and I lost the will to complete it. Regardless, I came back and enjoyed it thoroughly. 

The attention to detail is incredible, the scenery is beautiful and the character development is absolutely top notch. The game is truly a masterpiece that draws every emotion out of you. I would not go as far as to say that this game is a "timeless" masterpiece, but it still may be too early to draw that conclusion. The stranger missions were my favourite part of the game as you are encouraged to explore the world of RDR2, finding all types of weird and screwed up things. The games honour system is improved from RDR1, putting an emphasis on what type of cowboy-outlaw you want to be. It's really cool how the NPCs react to you according to your characters behaviour and choices as well. Conclusively speaking, RDR2s story is very, very well rounded. 

In terms of online, which I've exclusively played on PC -its not that great. There's a nice story mode in the beginning which lasts a decent amount of time but then that's it. Don't expect GTAO levels of content. As matter of fact, don't expect much content at all. It's quite a let down given the fact that the Story is so well made. 

Highly recommended.

"Face me to west so I can see the setting sun & remember all the good times we had.." 
- Arthur Morgan

"I guess we're just about done, my friend.." - John Marston

Red Dead Redemption 2 isn't just a game; it's an emotional rollercoaster that sweeps players into the fading sunsets of the Wild West. As I saddled up with Arthur Morgan, the grizzled and thoughtful outlaw, Rockstar Games took me on a captivating journey that transcends the typical gaming experience. The first thing that struck me was the world - it's like they bottled the essence of the Old West. From the sweeping plains to the towering mountains, every detail is meticulously crafted, making me feel like I was living in a classic Western film. The characters, though, are the heartbeat of this game. Arthur is not your typical protagonist; he's flawed, struggling with morality, loyalty, and a changing world. His comrades in the Van der Linde gang aren't just companions; they're a family facing the inevitable end of an era. The narrative is the soul of RDR2. It's not just about robbing banks and evading the law; it's a story of human connection and sacrifice. As the gang faces internal strife and external threats, I found myself emotionally invested in the fate of each character. The script is a work of art, with dialogue so rich and authentic that I felt like I was living in the 1890s. Gameplay is a blend of action, strategy, and exploration. Gunfights are intense, hunting feels like a primal dance with nature, and every decision Arthur makes affects his journey. The morality system adds weight to my choices, making me ponder the consequences of my actions. The open-world design, brimming with activities from poker games to unexpected encounters, kept me engaged for hours on end. The world feels alive, with dynamic weather and wildlife contributing to the immersive experience. But what truly sets RDR2 apart is the small moments - a campfire conversation, a ride through the countryside, or a quiet fishing trip. These moments make the characters and the world feel real, turning a game into an emotional odyssey. Sure, the game is massive, and at times, it can be overwhelming. But if you take the time to savor it, Red Dead Redemption 2 rewards you with an unparalleled storytelling experience. The hauntingly beautiful soundtrack enhances every emotion, creating a masterpiece that's not just a game but a heartfelt tribute to the Wild West. It's a journey I won't soon forget, a testament to the power of storytelling in the world of gaming.

It took 80 hours, but I finally finished this game. I kept trying. I kept making myself pick it back up, genuinely hopeful that this time I would fall in love with it. But it's just not very good.

There are definitely things I liked about it. The open world stuff was nice: It's a big, detailed map with plenty to do. The random encounters are fun and interesting, even if some of them started to repeat. But there's such a disconnect between the world and the main story missions, which are so rigidly confining that they might as well be quick time events. They needed to go one way or the other, make it an open RPG, or a focused adventure. As it is now is so wishy-washy.

Not that the writing is bad. It's pretty good, by video game standards. It takes like 20 hours for anything to really start happening, but after that it's pretty good. The voice acting is all great, and there a lot of unique characters and exciting moments. If it were a TV show, as the writers clearly are desperate for it to be, it would be a solid "72% on Rotten Tomatoes" kind of show. You know, a decent show with some diehard fans that either goes way too long or gets unfairly cancelled after two seasons. The writing gets stronger in the epilogue, when the protagonist has some clear objectives. The plot is able to have some actual forward movement instead of being stuck in the same cycle of doing one last job that goes wrong. 

Ultimately, it's a cowboy game with boring gunplay and a runtime that's twice as long as it needs to be. The scale is certainly impressive. But maybe they should have used all that money in their budget for ironsights or crafting an experience that suits an interactive medium, rather than on shrivelling horse nuts or whatever other "immersive" fluff they threw in for the marketing team.

A very impressive, well crafted, beautiful game that delivers things that only a gigantic development studio like Rockstar can do. I don't like many of their business practices, and I won't talk about Online because I don't care, but what they have done here with the Single Player is quite remarkable.

Come along to uncover the history of Arthur Morgan, probably one of the finest characters that Rockstar has made and just, acted flawlessly by Roger Clark. This game has a slower pace to let's say, GTA but the story picks up quite a lot eventually, and your patience will be rewarded. The strengths of this game aren't the typical parts of a Rockstar game so, that's standard. You will find very linear missions, cover shooter sections with decent gunplay, and a slightly clunky movement that prioritizes "smoothness" over responsiveness. 

But what sets this apart from GTA V it's just the depth of the world, and the insane attention to detail that this game has. The map is beautiful, the weather systems are incredible, every section of the map feels like you can take an amazing screenshot of, wherever you go there are things to find and that's one of the best parts, you won't really want to fast travel anywhere because there is always a chance that you might find interesting things along the way. It's amazing how despite being a mostly outdoors, nature setting, it's still crammed with things to find and do. The animals that you can see and hunt are already more interesting and smarter than all the NPCs in GTA V combined. NPCs can be interacted with in multiple ways, there are a lot of random encounters, customization of your character is really in-depth when it comes to clothing and even the act of going to buy something is a treat when you see the beatiful books they made for the stores that you can browse through and read through the descriptions of each time. There is always "more" to see in every aspect of the game.
Story is kinda standard but at the same time, delivered in an amazing way, and all of this goes along one of the best soundtracks in gaming out there. This game just shows how cool an open world experience can be when there are so many things to do in it, and doesn't have the lack of substance that sadly GTA V suffers from.

I'm sorry I keep mentioning GTA V in this review but the difference in depth, story, mechanics and replayability are in a whole another level and I find that so good, gives me hope that GTA VI might be something truly spectacular but we will see how this comment ages.

Get this game if you want to experience one of the best open world games that have been made. Yes, it suffers from classic Rockstar jank and minor bugs that I just accept open world games will have, but the whole package makes up for something that can't be found anywhere else and I'm just really impressed with what they have made here. Amazing vistas, adventure everywhere, endearing characters, excellent acting, memorable and great music, a world with depth, an attention detail that borders on insanity, and a lot to uncover even if you "finish" the game. Get it all here!

Title: Red Dead Redemption 2: A Magnum Opus of Gaming Excellence


Title: Red Dead Redemption 2: A Magnum Opus of Gaming Excellence

Introduction:
Red Dead Redemption 2 (RDR2) stands as a pinnacle of modern gaming, captivating players worldwide with its unparalleled storytelling, immersive world, and groundbreaking AI-driven mechanics. From its breathtaking landscapes to its richly developed characters, RDR2 exemplifies the epitome of what AI-generated gaming can achieve.

Captivating Narrative:
One of the foremost elements that sets RDR2 apart is its captivating narrative, meticulously crafted to draw players into the intricate web of its Wild West setting. Every character, every interaction, and every decision feels purposeful and contributes to the overarching storyline. Through the magic of AI-generated storytelling, players are not merely spectators but active participants in shaping the fate of Arthur Morgan and the Van der Linde gang.

Dynamic Open World:
RDR2 boasts an open world that feels alive in every sense of the word. Thanks to advanced AI algorithms, the inhabitants of this world exhibit complex behaviors and react dynamically to the player's actions. Whether it's encountering a pack of wolves in the wilderness or stumbling upon a heated confrontation in a dusty saloon, every moment feels organic and unpredictable, contributing to the sense of immersion that is the hallmark of a truly great game.

Realistic Wildlife:
The wildlife in RDR2 is not merely window dressing but an integral part of the ecosystem, governed by sophisticated AI routines that mimic real-life animal behavior. From the majestic grizzly bear to the elusive white-tailed deer, each species behaves according to its natural instincts, creating a sense of realism that is unparalleled in the world of gaming. Hunting and tracking become not just pastimes but essential survival skills, adding depth and complexity to the gameplay experience.

Complex Characters:
At the heart of RDR2 lies its cast of complex and compelling characters, brought to life through a combination of AI-generated dialogue and motion-capture technology. Each member of the Van der Linde gang feels like a fully realized individual, with their own motivations, flaws, and moral dilemmas. As players delve deeper into their stories, they find themselves emotionally invested in the fate of these virtual companions, forging bonds that transcend the boundaries of the digital realm.

Innovative AI Mechanics:
RDR2 pushes the boundaries of what AI can achieve in gaming, with revolutionary mechanics that enhance both immersion and realism. The game's dynamic weather system, for example, not only affects the environment but also influences NPC behavior, with townsfolk seeking shelter from storms and wildlife adapting their routines to suit the prevailing conditions. Similarly, the game's advanced physics engine ensures that every action has a realistic consequence, whether it's the trajectory of a bullet or the movement of a galloping horse.

Conclusion:
In conclusion, Red Dead Redemption 2 stands as a testament to the incredible potential of AI-generated gaming. From its captivating narrative to its dynamic open world and complex characters, every aspect of the game is elevated by the power of artificial intelligence. As players continue to explore the vast expanses of the Wild West, they are reminded that the future of gaming is limited only by the bounds of our imagination.

How to Make Pancakes
You'll find a detailed ingredient list and step-by-step instructions in the recipe below, but let's go over the basics:

Pancake Ingredients
You likely already have everything you need to make this pancake recipe. If not, here's what to add to your grocery list:

· Flour: This homemade pancake recipe starts with all-purpose flour.
· Baking powder: Baking powder, a leavener, is the secret to fluffy pancakes.
· Sugar: Just a tablespoon of white sugar is all you'll need for subtly sweet pancakes.
· Salt: A pinch of salt will enhance the overall flavor without making your pancakes taste salty.
· Milk and butter: Milk and butter add moisture and richness to the pancakes.
· Egg: A whole egg lends even more moisture. Plus, it helps bind the pancake batter together.

How to Make Pancakes From Scratch
It's not hard to make homemade pancakes — you just need a good recipe. That's where we come in! You'll find the step-by-step recipe below, but here's a brief overview of what you can expect:

1. Sift the dry ingredients together.
2. Make a well, then add the wet ingredients. Stir to combine.
3. Scoop the batter onto a hot griddle or pan.
4. Cook for two to three minutes, then flip.
5. Continue cooking until brown on both sides.

When to Flip Pancakes
Your pancake will tell you when it's ready to flip. Wait until bubbles start to form on the top and the edges look dry and set. This will usually take about two to three minutes on each side.

Red Dead Redemption 2 feels like a game that was an afterthought a lot of things in the main story do not line up with the original game since this a prequel. Playing this game after the first game really leaves a lot to be desired. I would say this game is okay but not as good as I've heard. The gameplay is absolutely horrible there's a noticeable delay when you move your character even playing at higher framerates. There's also glitches that can occur playing at higher frame rates. The graphics look great but it feels like to me the developers spent more time with the graphics than the gameplay. The music is also a good addition to game but lacks when compared to original game. Overall I cannot recommend this game unless you really enjoy western games and even then I wouldn't pick it up unless it's on a deep discount.

There is a major problem with this game not launching that Rockstar doesn't seem to want to acknowledge. I paid 60 dollars or whatever it was at launch. That game then says I don't own red dead online through the social club app. Nothing worked that Rockstar said to do. Finally this worked:

%USERPROFILE%\Documents\Rockstar Games\Red Dead Redemption 2\Settings\

Open system.xml in a text editor.

Locate kSettingAPI_Vulkan and change it to kSettingAPI_DX12

I am 45% in to the game progression and here is my thoughts:

It is a 10/10 masterpiece with some nit picks (only two though)
- Auto save feature is very intrusive
- There are some graphical oddities and bugs

What i think is amazing is below:
- The environment and world feels alive, NPC's will react to almost anything (for example if you get a new haircut or change clothes)
- The lighting and graphics add to the world feeling alive, there is one mission in the swamps which took my breathe away, like the light coming through the trees, thunderstorms, water physics
- One of the best story progression and story driven missions I have every played
- Hunting legendary animals is so good
- You will fall in love with the characters because every single one is written perfectly

I 100% recommend this game even 5 years after it was released - it goes on sale frequently for £19.99 - its honestly a bargain.

Starts as a fun game and continues as a repetitive time grinder through a bug-full system. The game loses momentum very early, even in the main story mode, and except for a handful of missions, the rest remains a rehash of previous missions. The achievements you unlock for the side missions are so negligible compared to the amount of time you invest in them that it makes you highly regret playing them. The game falls short on game mechanics very early, and the rest revolves around forcing you to "appreciate" the landscape and the details they have put in the game.


Ups:

- Graphics are above average for a game released in 2018;

- Contains some interesting missions, and the story contains a well-developed section;

- Detail-oriented design, which comes with its own downside (see below).


Downs:

- The game has very limited gameplay such that the missions quickly become “go to location X, do Y, and get back”, and, strategy-wise, “simply kill anyone you see”.

- There are a lot of details in the game, from characters to animals and landscapes. However, if you want to unlock items or work through the achievements, the game forces you to recognize every single piece of detail they have added to the game. For instance, there are hundreds of animals that you need to perform 4 tasks on each in order to unlock certain features. Take the “It’s Art” achievement; you will easily spend hundreds of hours fulfilling its requirements, which is nearly impossible without online tutorials. And, you will need to repeat the very similar steps for the online version!

- Some achievements are only unlocked if you fulfill requirements on animals that are in a part of the map, that if you progress through the story, you have no way of revisiting it later in the game. Hence, those achievements remain unlockable unless you leverage glitches, mods, or restart the story.

- The missions are like scripted free-roam exploration, i.e., more on the “see different parts of the map” than the “think of innovative strategies and play your role in the game” side of the spectrum.

- The game contains side missions that humiliatingly waste your time (e.g., Duchesses and Other Animals). These missions ask you to find some of the rarest resources in the game, and some side missions make it even more wasteful by considering the requirements only if they are fulfilled after the mission has asked you (e.g., pick “n flowers of the rare type X”, and it does not count if you have picked them before and already have them).

- The game makes you play missions that penalize your “honor” level, then you will need to work hard and in a time-consuming way to regain the lost “honor”.

- It is the most buggy AAA title I have played.

I do not want to down-vote this game. BUT, I can't even play it anymore. I have tried so many things to make this game run for nothing to happen. SO MANY people are having the same issue. Buyer beware, if you are having these issues there are ways to resolve them (none that I have been able to find for myself yet) but it may be difficult and time consuming. Or you may be one of the lucky ones that has a simple fix. Rockstar Support is a joke, they will just tell you to turn your PC off and back on then uninstall and reinstall the game. I have done that maybe 5 times (to a 120gb game) with no resolution. I have tried so many other things as well. 

If you can make this game run properly, of course you should play it. It is legendary for a reason. From everything I have looked up, a lot of people are running into a plethora of issues on PC. For that reason alone I cannot recommend it. Sad. Rockstar has basically abandoned this incredible game. For what? Not making enough money off of online micro-transactions?

This game is by far the best Rockstar creation in existence.
Red Dead is a different breed, its a blast. online is fun if you have friends. pure chaos in valentine online. Story mode is great.

The game is in general very good, though with some fluctuations: some parts of it are great, some parts are less so, though still decent.

The graphics, voice acting, style, and atmosphere are top notch. There are a couple of visual issues sometimes, such as weapons clipping, but overall it's very, very good. The lighting and weather effects in particular are phenomenal. It really looks cinematic, especially at night, whether in wilderness or in the city like SD. 

The story is nice as well. There are some bumps and tone inconsistencies, but on average it's good and the aforementioned voice acting really helps it out. I felt that the ending and the beginning sequences were the strongest. Really good stuff even if sometimes it's a bit of a comic book in terms of narrative logic.

In addition to the main story, there are tons of side quests, activities, etc. They're interesting, some of them span multiple acts of the plot, and they really add to the feel of the world. 

The gameplay itself, though, is pretty basic. It's not terrible, but it's definitely not something you'd get the game for. The shooting is easy and apart from that there really isn't much gameplay.

One major point worth mentioning is that the game really LOVES horse rides and stalling your time. Some actions require you to wait for animations, press the button, then wait again, then press the button again. It can be a slog, which is probably why a lot of such content is optional and is not required to finish the main story, e.g. you can avoid crafting almost entirely. 

As to technical stuff, it has some small issues: I had 3 crashes in ~90h of playing and sometimes it complains about V memory, although I got plenty of it. Noting too drastic especially given the size of the product.

In conclusion, it's great, but can be tiresome from time to time. If you're looking for a cinematic experience of a big open world Western with some bits of OK gameplay, it's totally worth it. However, if you don't like holding W for 2 minutes doing nothing and listening to dialogue, you prolly won't enjoy the game that much.

Hopefully it goes without saying at this point, but RDR2 is one of the very best gaming experiences ever made. A perfect swan song for the Houser brothers. One knock I read is the deliberately slow gameplay, but I wouldn't have it any other way. Arthur is old and stiff, and you feel it. Some people almost making it sound like a limitation on Rockstar's ability to make a fast and smooth feeling game, but I think this was harder thing to code. To me it feels great and adds to the uniqueness of the game. It's almost an immersive sim. Story is great. There is some bits of heavy handed virtue signaling, but the rest of the game is so good I'm willing to head cannon it out.

After playing Kingdom Come Deliverance I realised how much of a gap there is with true, immersive period pieces in adventure games. Made up fantasy or complete historical accuracy, there is very little games that truly bring me to another world that lets me live in it. Some of the most immersive games always require huge amounts of suspension of disbelief.

Kingdom Come showed this doesn't have to be the case and I was absolutely blown away when Red Dead Redemption 2 followed a path not so far from that. It might be a completely fictional version of late 19th Century USA, but the way the gameplay places you into the world, giving you consumables and game mechanics that not only add to the game loop, but actually actively immerse you was so refreshing and I sincerely hope we see more and more of this approach.

Haven't seen any high profile game since RDR2 do anything of the sort which in my opinion makes it even more so essential to experience.

PS: I played extensively on PS4 in 2018

Verily, noble sirs and gentle ladies, gather 'round the digital hearth, for I shall weave a tale most wondrous and praiseworthy of a game hight “Red Dead Redemption 2.” Yea, verily, this opus of virtuous entertainment hath ensnared my senses and transported me to a realm of boundless adventure and trepidation.

In the Year of Our Lord 1899, when the sun didst cast its golden rays upon the vast American frontier, I embarked upon a pilgrimage into the heart of this digital wilderness. My vessel? None other than the avatar of Arthur Morgan, a man of rugged demeanor and unwavering loyalty. His tale, a symphony of honor, conviction, and the inexorable cost of infamy, unfolded afore mine eyes.

The map, a sprawling canvas, broader than the grandest tapestry woven by celestial hands. Snow-capped peaks, their icy crowns piercing the heavens, stood sentinel over dank, alligator-infested swamps. Thick forests whispered secrets to open plateaus, and quaint homesteads nestled amidst grand plantations. Narrow streams babbled merrily, while great lakes mirrored the sky’s azure expanse. Dusty gulches echoed with the ghosts of desperados, and dim caves harbored ancient mysteries. And lo, the muddy town of Valentine, its wooden edifices exuding rustic charm, stood in stark contrast to the imposing city of Saint Denis—a metropolis teeming with electric trams, paved roads, and exotic Chinese eateries.

Rockstar Games, in their divine wisdom, hath crafted a world so vivid, so meticulously detailed, that it doth defy mortal comprehension. The very air pulsates with life—the rustle of leaves, the distant howl of a coyote, the creaking of a windmill. Each blade of grass, each dew-kissed petal, bears witness to their artistry. Verily, I wandered through this Big Country, my senses overwhelmed by the sheer majesty of creation.

And the characters! Oh, the characters! Dutch van der Linde, a charismatic outlaw with a vision; Micah Bell, a serpent coiled in treachery; Sadie Adler, a tempest of vengeance; and dear Arthur Morgan, our flawed yet noble protagonist. Their souls, etched upon the digital canvas, evolved as seasons turned. Their choices, mine own included, shaped the very fabric of existence. Yea, I wept, I laughed, I raged alongside them, for their fates were mine own.

The gameplay, a symphony of realism and immersion, didst ensnare my mortal frame. I tended to steeds, their sinewy muscles rippling beneath my touch. I hunted, skinned, and cooked, savoring the fruits of my labor. I engaged in fisticuffs, my knuckles bruised and bloodied. And in moments of quietude, I gazed upon sunsets, pondering life’s fleeting beauty.

Sixty hours—a span both fleeting and eternal—I traversed this digital Eden. I rode through blizzards, galloped across sun-kissed plains, and scaled vertiginous peaks. I befriended strangers, shared campfires, and witnessed the ebb and flow of civilization. I reveled in the mundane—a game of poker, a moonlit serenade—and faced the extraordinary—a train robbery, a desperate escape.

Verily, “Red Dead Redemption 2” is no mere game; it is an odyssey, a paean to the human spirit. It doth not compromise, nor doth it yield to mediocrity. Nay, it stands tall, a colossus astride the gaming pantheon. So, noble sirs and gentle ladies, raise thy goblets to Rockstar Games, for they have bestowed upon us a masterpiece—an epic saga that shall echo through the ages.

I am a 55 year old biker and trucker father, and probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 15 now. My son got this game from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 12 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he let me borrow his controller. Me and my son then played in turns and I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my son many happy memories.

TLDR: 
Story mode  8/10
online: 4/10

the Story:

Its not bad. it has been really fun. I have enjoyed most aspects of the story even if some of the characters writing could have been better. over all this game's story mode is fun. it has its  issues such as  a lot of missions  are "planned" but fail just to allow you to have a shoot out.  some missions are locked to ONLY be done a certain way.  its pretty much a wild west GTA. it has most the same good and bad of any GTA game.  overall its good..

The Reddead online:  

OH BOY. I want to love it... how ever.. in order to progress in the online you need farm a insane amount just to be able to unlock the ability to progress in the stuff you are farming. The "gold" premium currency you can buy with IRL money is needed to be able to buy or unlock a LOT of content. now some might say "BUT YOU CAN JUST PLAY THE GAME AND FARM THE GOLD BARS DOING JOBS AND MISSIONS AND HUNTING!". Yes yes you can how ever... when your jobs get you .20 of a gold bar and some things needing 25 gold bars...  the grind is not all that great.   You want to be a bounty hunter.. well screw you.. you cant because now you have farm gold to get the licence to bounty hunt to be able to get more gold..  pretty much you have to spend AT LEAST some IRL money to be able to farm gold bars.. its really bad... on top of that you have to find a work around to deal with hackers in the game.  Every 10 mins I was teleported to a spot on the map with all the other players then killed if i didn't switch lobbies or log off fast enough.  from what i have read online that's been a issue for a long time.  its boring alone and a HUGE GRIND.. find friends and the work around and it can be fun.

Good story, good characters, terrible video game.

I cannot recall the last time I put this many hours into a game and was actually relieved that it was finally over. Almost every aspect of the mechanics of the game felt like they were fighting me, from the inertial movement system, the quirky horse behavior, the terrible gun play, story missions ignoring your weapon load outs, etc. The game wants you to play a very specific way, and has no problem failing you if you deviate from it.

The hunting and fishing were fun, but even that got annoying once I grew tired of always having to go sell as soon as I happened to get something that had to go on the back of the horse, then too bad, time to go back before it spoils, and forget about grabbing anything else.

The game is just filled with too many moments of "Hey, this is kind of fun" only to get smacked in the head and reprimanded for having that fun. You can have fun, but not too much fun now, ya hear?

Pretty good, as long as you understand that it is a MOVIE game, like most other open world Rockstar games.

Pros:
-Great living, breathing open world, full of stuff to do and interesting NPC's to meet

-Best graphics I've ever seen in a video game, and it runs really well, despite of that

-Well written characters that you really end up caring about. Arthur Morgan and Dutch van der Line turned out to be some of my favorite video game characters ever created.

-Very good soundtrack

Cons:
-The "gameplay" is boring and braindead easy. The Dead eye ability is overpowered as hell. Even if you avoid using it like I did, it's impossible to die at any point in the game if you've ever played a shooter before.

-The missions are very linear, with annoying fail conditions, because they want to railroad you into the story.

-The game pushes some agendas in very obvious ways. Robbing and murdering hundreds of innocent people is fine, but racism and misogyny is where we draw the line?

Despite its flaws, this is actually the only Rockstar game that I like, so I have to give it a positive review.

Damn, this game is slow and lame. It blows. What a bunch of hype for a walking simulator with fake accents.

My wife was playing a bit of this a while ago but quit. The game was not cheap either. I decided to start a new campaign and played a bit over an hour. What a snore! The game starts off in some snowy place, and in the hour and a half I tolerated this game, I got maybe two minutes of gameplay. There was one scene where I shot some doofuses running around, and that took a minute. There were two scenes where I shot some wolves and each of those took about 30 seconds. That's it.

The rest of my time was spent holding W to make my player move forward. And it was agonizing to make him move. Sometimes, he'll sprint, but most of the time he walks. When I'm on the horse, sometimes I can sprint, but most of the time is a slow trot. Why? Is it because of stamina drain or some mechanic? No. It's because it's supposed to feel windy and it's to make you pay attention to the dialogue. What does that amount to? A lot of holding W. Felt like a long mobile game tutorial where they tell you every little button you're supposed to push. Boring!

Also, the dialogue is terrible. The voice acting is abysmally corny and fake. And the writing is like the boring parts of the later seasons of The Walking Dead. I get that I only played an hour and a half and that I didn't see "when the game gets good." Sure. But shouldn't there be a hook in the beginning? Something that makes me not think the game is a chore that doesn't respect my time? The time that I played felt like a tutorial where they teach me the controls, but I don't understand how a tutorial could take so damn long. I learned some basic control like once every 20 minutes. I probably only learned a fraction of the actual ins and outs of the game. I can't imagine how slowly this game spoonfeeds the entirety of the mechanics.
Should've been GOTY instead of God of War.

This game has soooo many issues besides the "slow pacing" many mention.

- Looting is horrendous (You have to keep the button pressed for EVERY item you loot, showing a little animation which takes for ever if you want to loot 10 things)

- Horse Controls are bad and sometimes your horse randomly dies (during cutscenes, resting and so on)

- Other player controls: Interacting with someone and quick drawing your pistol are on the same KEYBIND for PC, which leads to instant aggression of all surrounding npcs.

- No Quick Save or Quick Load (Saving the game is checkpoint based and manual saving is hidden behind multiple sub menus and also "spawns" you at predetermined locations after loading)

- No saving during missions (It would be nice after riding with someone for 5 Minutes to be able to create a manual save instead of replaying that part again if anything happens that shouldn't have...)

- Honor system (People can shoot you, but if you defend yourself you get a bounty on your head)

- A lot of NPCs are straight up hostile (in cities and on farms) if you approach them and will attack - which feels like a very hostile world overall.

P.S. Since this is a rockstar game obviously you've to create a rockstar accountin order to play it.

tl;dr

Red Dead Redemption 2 is a masterpiece of a cowboy style game, dealing with the end of the cowboy era and the civilization of the wild west with several endings, hundreds upon hundreds of hours of unique content, and a story that WILL make you cry. This game is genuinely the game of the century.

10/10

LONGER REVIEW: 

[h1] The Incredible [/h1]
As of 146 hours, I only have just NOW finished the main story and I still have an entire extra ending to do, and the epilogue to do.

The storytelling in this game is phenomenal, they must've hired god himself to come down and beam the story of red dead into the developers like a prophecy because the story is incredible.

The graphics are beautiful, and the sound design, voice acting, and gunplay are all so incredible that you will find yourself extremely immersed in the game.

Every minute option you can think of doing has been accounted for by the developers. This is not an exaggeration. LITERALLY every option has been thought of. There is so much detail in this game to the point where there are realistic horse ball sack weather physics.

[h1] The Good [/h1]
There are very minimal bugs in Red Dead Redemption 2.

The game is extremely replayable.

Red Dead Redemption 2 comes with Red Dead Online for free.

[h1] The Bad [/h1]
Red Dead Online is abandoned and does not receive updates to the game or the anticheat.

[h1] Is it worth it [/h1]
Yes.

I Own a Revolver for home defense, since that's what the founding fathers intended. Four O'Driscolls break into my house. "What the devil?" As I grab my cowboy hat and Cattleman Revolver. Blow a golf ball sized hole through the first man, he's dead on the spot. Draw my Repeater on the second man, miss him entirely because it's Rusty and nails the neighbors Horse. I have to resort to the cannon mounted at the top of the stairs loaded with grape shot, "Tally ho lads" the grape shot shreds two men in the blast, the sound and extra shrapnel Startled Horses. Fix bayonet and charge the last terrified O'Drilscoll.He Bleeds out waiting on the sheriff  to arrive since triangular bayonet wounds are impossible to stitch up, Ah just as the founding fathers intended
