Top tier story 10/10

A cowboy is an animal herder who tends cattle on ranches in North America, traditionally on horseback, and often performs a multitude of other ranch-related tasks. The historic American cowboy of the late 19th century arose from the vaquero traditions of northern Mexico and became a figure of special significance and legend.[1] A subtype, called a wrangler, specifically tends the horses used to work cattle. In addition to ranch work, some cowboys work for or participate in rodeos. Cowgirls, first defined as such in the late 19th century, had a less-well documented historical role, but in the modern world work at identical tasks and have obtained considerable respect for their achievements.[2] Cattle handlers in many other parts of the world, particularly South America and stockmen and jackaroos in Australia, perform work similar to the cowboy.

The cowboy has deep historic roots tracing back to Spain and the earliest European colonizers of the Americas. Over the centuries, differences in terrain and climate, and the influence of cattle-handling traditions from multiple cultures, created several distinct styles of equipment, clothing and animal handling. As the ever-practical cowboy adapted to the modern world, his equipment and techniques also adapted, though many classic traditions are preserved.

One of the best games I've ever played, hands down. If you enjoy watching country western/spaghetti western movies, you'll love this game. It's paced very similarly to the movies of the same ilk. Imagine all the fun of GTA but set in the 19th century America. Lots of fun stuff to do as well as lots of fun little Easter eggs and references to some popular things of the time period in real life, like seeing people building homes they purchased from the Sears-Roebuck catalog, watching railroad workers ACTUALLY building the railroad as opposed to seeing an NPC animation loop playing in perpetuity. You can hunt, go fishing, there's an honor system that actually impacts how the world interacts with you. That's just the story mode/offline I described. There's an online mode that is tons of fun and only gets better if you download RedM which is the RDR2 equivalent of FiveM (the super popular GTA V online client which allows for mods/modded servers that you see streamers playing GTA V in role playing mode in servers like NoPixel and other similar servers) so you can expand upon the already super vast world and activities included in the base game. This mod/client is free and it's 10000% a must have because it just gives you sooo many more things to do, infinitely increasing the amount of fun to be had. I remember when this game first came out and I was skeptical at first about how good it actually could be but then I caught it on sale on here a couple years ago and figured ah what the hell why not try it. I am SO glad I bought it because it is literally one of the best games I've ever played in my life. Gameplay is excellent, controls are intuitive, atmosphere is amazing, soundtrack is on point, And the story?? Tuhhhhh mmbbooiieeee just buy the damn game. You'll be doing yourself a huge favor.

I thought RDR2 was just a classic wild west game for some shootouts and horseback riding. But as I played, I realized it's much more than that. This is a story about Arthur Morgan, a complex outlaw, and his fellow gang members, that are just as authentic, with their own motivations and flaws. This emotional connection whether it be Arthur's internal battles or the gang member's tribulations, draws you into their journey and makes you genuinely care about their outcomes. The game explores themes of redemption and loyalty while offering a vast world full of stories to discover. With multiple endings, you can shape Arthur's fate, adding depth to the experience. Overall, RDR2 stands out for its great characters, emotional depth, and extremely immersive world, making it a standout example of storytelling in gaming. 1000/BOAH

I don't even have words to describe this game. At this point, I don't even know if I can call it a game. I feel like it's appropriate to call it a cowboy simulator. The plot, characters, dialogue are all 10/10 movie level. Gameplay has so much detail people are still getting surprised with stuff they find nowadays. You can watch a butcher NPC cut a slab of meat, see the meat get sliced into individual pieces, see the butcher pick up the individual pieces of meat he cut into a basket, and see that basket fill up with the pieces of meat. The immersion is just unmatched. On a technical level this is as close to perfection as we've ever seen. The amount of hours I've played is 90% Red Dead Online with friends which, despite being the piece of **** that it is, riddled with hackers and unsupported by Rocksh*t, just speaks volumes on the quality of this game. 1000/10

Had my eye on this game for a while. Read the comments and watched a bunch of play thru on You Tube. Liked what I saw and decided since it was on sale to give it a go.
Did the sign up with Social Club and off I went.
My initial reaction was "Wow" nice graphics (I have a good enough rig to give me nice results) Game mechanics are going to take a while but it looks like a very involving game.
OK did the first scenario/mission and went to try Online.
Was playing online for about an hour when I was approached by somebody offering to help the obvious noob.
I had no need up until that time to use voice chat so I didn't know which button to push. He kept on talking but I could not reply until I went to the settings and found that the "N" key allowed voice chat. I did not want to show aggressiveness to the other player so I turned my back to him and crouched. He came up from behind and shot me in the head.
When I re spawned back onto the map my character burst into flame! As I was near a river I ran into it but the water did not put out the flames. Went back on shore and kept burning until my character died. This happened two more times. Spawn set on fire, die spawn set on fire, die. As I was waiting to re spawn this guy asks if I'm having trouble. I explained the situation and presto, I re spawned not on fire. Asked him if he did that and he said "Maybe."
I asked him how long has he been playing and he answered since the game came out.
Said he would help me with obtaining money. I told him that I wanted to buy the collectors bag from the ♥♥♥♥♥ but didn't have enough money to do so.
Well this player (by the way he did not speak with any obvious accent) was able to create crates for me to loot. I did so and gained cash nuggets and other items. When I went to the ♥♥♥♥♥ to buy and sell what ever I had looted from the crates none of it registered. While he was creating crates and I tried looting them a couple of buddies came up carrying tied up captives. they were dumped on the ground untied then shot.
This guy wanted to "friend" me.
This kind of game experience I do not want or need.
I have removed the game from my library and uninstalled from my computer. Also requested to be removed from Social Club.
DO NOT BUY THIS GAME!!!!!!!!!!!
I did and I'm out $19.80 plus tax for a total of $20.89.

Overview:
Red Dead Redemption 2, developed by Rockstar Games, is an epic tale set in the dying days of the Wild West. As Arthur Morgan, players navigate through a beautifully crafted open world, engaging in thrilling gunfights, immersive storytelling, and morally complex decision-making.

Graphics and Sound:
Visually stunning, the game transports players to a meticulously detailed world filled with breathtaking landscapes, bustling towns, and diverse wildlife. From the rugged mountains to the murky swamps, every environment feels alive and authentic. Accompanied by a hauntingly beautiful score, the sound design further enhances the immersive experience.

Gameplay:
Red Dead Redemption 2 offers a blend of action-packed gunplay and slow-paced exploration. Whether hunting legendary animals, robbing trains, or engaging in intense shootouts, every moment feels dynamic and consequential. The game's attention to detail is evident in its realistic horse mechanics, intricate gun customization, and varied side activities like fishing and poker.

Story and Characters:
At its heart, Red Dead Redemption 2 is a story about loyalty, redemption, and the fading of an era. The rich narrative weaves together themes of family, honor, and survival, as players follow Arthur Morgan's journey through the Van der Linde gang's struggles. The cast of characters is diverse and memorable, each with their own motivations and flaws, adding depth to the overall storytelling.

Replay Value:
With its expansive world and branching storylines, Red Dead Redemption 2 offers endless opportunities for exploration and replayability. Optional missions, random encounters, and moral choices ensure that each playthrough feels unique, encouraging players to uncover hidden secrets and discover new paths.

Conclusion:
Red Dead Redemption 2 stands as a testament to Rockstar Games' commitment to storytelling and immersive gameplay. With its breathtaking visuals, compelling narrative, and vast open world, it sets a new standard for the Western genre in gaming. Whether you're a fan of action-adventure games or simply appreciate a well-crafted story, Red Dead Redemption 2 is an experience not to be missed.

In a recent tweet, an indie game developer referred to Baldur's Gate 3 as a gaming anomaly. While I absolutely adore BG3, especially for the fact that it brought the rather niche genre of CRPGs to a broader audience, the true anomaly in the world of video games is Red Dead Redemption 2 for me.

What truly set this game apart from others, is the remarkable level of attention to detail evident in every facet of its design. Every individual you encounter follows their own daily routine, from constructing houses to initiating a bar brawl on their own, or simply basking in the sun after a hunting expedition - and this is just the tip of the iceberg. Throughout my numerous playthroughs, there were countless moments where I found myself engrossed in my surroundings, and at times, the game even rewarded my careful observation with small stories. For instance, while I was on my way to procure some food for our camp, I spotted a distant plume of smoke on the horizon. I cautiously rode towards it, took cover behind a tree, and watched to discern the situation. There, I found several veterans of the Civil War who had been defeated by the Northern states and were now engaged in some form of guerrilla warfare against their "oppressors." From my concealed vantage point, I overheard them discussing fallen comrades and lamenting the sorry state of the world after the war. In another example I found myself fishing by a picturesque pond in a valley encircled by mountains, where I could keenly observe the wildlife going about their activities. The sight of a bald eagle snatching a fish from the water right in front of me was incredibly captivating to witness. These are merely a few minor examples within a world teeming with intricacies for players to explore, many of which may go unnoticed by the majority of players.

Another significant aspect that I genuinely appreciate is the deliberate slow pacing. Everything you undertake carries weight and feels quite realistic. Whether it's working in the camp, chopping wood, cooking meat, or crafting arrows, it all takes its time. I can't commend Rockstar enough for adopting this approach because it tremendously enhances your immersion in this world and your role as Arthur. You can truly role-play as Arthur, even though he's a well-defined character with his own mind and thoughts. He even maintains his own journal where you can delve into his innermost desires and anxieties. With each experience you share with him, you develop a deeper sense of empathy, especially in the last two chapters.

It's not only the main protagonist who is exceptionally well-written, all the side characters, especially your gang members, possess unique and non-cliché personalities. The gang's leader, Dutch van der Linde, is particularly intriguing because his true identity and intentions aren't immediately apparent. As you get to know him better, you can perceive the complexities behind the facade of a charismatic leader figure who grapples with profound self-doubt and regrets. To be honest, if I were in Arthur's situation, living in that era and with his history, I'd likely follow this man to the ends of the earth as well.

From a technical perspective, the game looks incredibly impressive. Each frame could be a painting crafted by a 19th-century landscape artist. The atmospheric lighting, particularly in Saint Denis at night, is awe-inspiring. One time, I ventured to the highest mountain and observed a complete day and night cycle, and it looked remarkably realistic and sharp. When you simply explore the open world, nearly all your senses are engaged, from the chirping of birds to the sound of horses' hooves or the howling of a pack of wolves.

The soundtrack consistently strikes the perfect notes for every situation. Some key story moments excel primarily because the right song accompanies them. There were numerous instances where I experienced goosebumps solely from the soundtrack. Certain tracks also feature a significant instrumental post-rock influence, which happens to be one of my favorite genres, and I truly appreciate that. For instance, the moment when you return from Guarma and ride back to camp ranks among my favorite moments in video game history because it masterfully conveys Arthur's current state without relying on words – it's a prime example of "show don't tell."

Now, concerning the main plot, I believe the developers were avid enthusiasts of anti-Western literature, such as "Butcher's Crossing," or films like "There Will Be Blood." They skillfully toy with the romantic clichés of the American West and turn them on their heads. The central theme of a world you're familiar with gradually descending into chaos is depicted with great attention to subtle details and expertly crafted, realistic dialogue. Rockstar has so much to tell, and you can't help but become fully engaged, even in smaller side narratives. For instance, there's the story of a circus troupe that lost its main attraction, a large tiger that escaped and is now causing turmoil on a small farm, or the tale of a despondent gunslinger who can't find solace after the "heroic" deeds he performed in the past.

If I were to be critical and nitpick certain aspects I didn't like, it would be that Rockstar could have pushed the boundaries of realism further in game design. For instance, they could have implemented a more extended day and night cycle or a heightened level of realism in a survival mode where you'd need to eat and sleep daily. Additionally, there are moments when the wildlife doesn't behave naturally. For example, it's hard to imagine that a healthy, well-fed pack of wolves would casually attack a human on horseback just passing through their territory. There are also instances where deer seemingly appear out of nowhere, making it feel like they are conveniently placed for the player to hunt on their way to the next objective. Also Arthur can take way too much bullets before he dies, especially with a full health core, again i would've liked a more realistic approach, but taken that rockstar has it's roots in more arcady game series like GTA i can understand this aspect to not fully loose a majority of their playerbase.

Red Dead Redemption 2 is possibly the greatest game ever, a contemporary masterpiece of art that may well remain relevant even a decade or two from now.

Red Dead Redemption 2 surprised me with how much I enjoyed it. The world never felt empty with each new area having a distinct atmosphere that separated it from the others. The gameplay on a steam deck, while killing the battery pretty quickly, was nice overall. In my 67 hours I had 3 times where the game crashed and I had to replay part of a mission. Each time it did crash was during a fighting sequence in a story mission, so at least the game had saved recently each time.
The characters at the beginning felt like there were too many to keep track up, but with this long of a game there was plenty of time to get to know each one to at least some extent. Characters I thought I'd dislike the whole game ended up being some of the ones I loved by the end and vice versa!

I was able to get the game on sale for $15 and honestly for that price the game is a steal. At 67 hours I completed the main story, including epilogues, and a good handful of side missions for a completion percentage in game showing at 80%. Heck, even if you picked the game up for full price and just stuck to the main story I feel like you can easily get 50 hours of interesting and enjoyable gameplay and story. Definitely worth even that price for how much polished content you get. With that being said though, you might as well get it on a killer sale and be fine if you feel like the game isn't for you by the second chapter.

Would highly recommend, good detail, story, and so much to do i have played this for 15 hours already and have barely made a dent in the story. Got the game on sale for $20 best amount of money i could've spent.

This Game's campaign is very good at getting you immersed in the story, and has made me feel almost every emotion throughout the game. since this game made me laugh and cry, i give it a 10/10.
I highly recommend this game to anyone that enjoys open world adventure games.

On the other hand, there is the online multiplayer. I don't enjoy it unless I am playing with friends, and even when I am, most of the content is locked behind tedious grinding. Compared to the story mode, obtaining money is significantly harder, and all purchasable items are higher priced then in the campaign. It cost me $140 to buy a blue poncho, and guess what the developers did to solve this? Buyable currency that can be used to pay for almost anything. This includes special jobs that can earn you money significantly easier. This currency can be earned, but at a very slow pace. after playing for about 3 hours, I have 3/4s of what i need to buy a bounty hunting license. It just sounds like a ploy to get me to purchase the currency instead of working for it. 
 Despite my ranting, if you are just playing to dick around with your friends, go for it, but any sort of ranking up takes ages. 6/10

How to Cook Pork Adobo

Marinate The Pork Belly In Soy Sauce And Crushed Garlic
The first thing to do is marinate the pork belly in soy sauce and crushed garlic. It is best to marinate it overnight. If time is limited, one hour should be enough. Some like to add vinegar during the process. You may do so if preferred.

Brown The Marinated Pork
Drain the marinade. Save it for later. The marinated pork needs to be browned. Heat a cooking pot. Add pork with garlic. You can also add a few tablespoons of cooking oil. Cook the pork until it turns brown.

Pour Water And Add The Spices
Cook the pork until tender. Do this by pouring the remaining marinade, if any. Also add water. Let the liquid boil.

This is the part where I put the whole peppercorn and dried bay leaves. These ingredients complete my pork adobo. Boiling for 40 minutes should be enough to tenderize the pork. There are times when you have to cook longer.

Add The Vinegar
If you have not added the vinegar as part of the marinade, pour it into the pot and let it cook for 10 minutes. Salt is an optional ingredient for this recipe. Use it only if you think it is needed.

Season
Taste the sauce first so that you know what seasonings to add. Since we already added a good amount of soy sauce, salt might not be needed. However, this depends on your preference. You can also add more water here if you think that then saltiness is on the upper side. Sometimes I also add a dash of sugar to balance the flavor.

Adobo Alternative And Additional Ingredients
Pork – Use any cut of pork that you prefer. I suggest pork belly for best results. However, use leaner parts if you are trying to avoid fats. Pork tenderloin is a healthier choice. This is very tender and contains way less fat than pork belly. You can also use other proteins such as chicken and goat meat using this recipe.

Onion – This recipe does not suggest the use of onion. I think that onions help improve the taste of adobo. Use red, yellow, or white onion for this recipe. Make sure to chop it into small pieces.

Dried Bay Leaves – this is an ingredient that you can almost always find most of the time in the spice section of your local supermarket. Believe it or not, but this makes a huge difference when cooking adobo.

Whole Peppercorn – this is a traditional ingredient. It will not matter if you use crushed peppercorn or ground black pepper. Sichuan peppercorns are also good alternatives.

Sugar – adding a teaspoon of sugar will move your pork adobo on the sweeter side. I personally love the taste of adobo with a bit of sugar.

Try this Pork Adobo Recipe and let me know what you think.

This game is an exceptional work of art for this generation, which is uncommon for AAA games now-days. It's the sort that maybe only comes out once every ten years from a company like Rockstar Games. The experience one can have is beyond words. With its outstanding story, complex characters, and a rich open world that redefined the industry. 

It comes as no surprise that, even after being released in 2018, it is still the greatest open-world story-driven game ever made. Rockstar raised the bar so high with this game that most AAA games these days are unable to match the amount of detail that Rockstar has put into it. 

A game like this only comes around once in a lifetime, therefore I'm thankful I got to experience it.

It's been a long few years since I've started this game. Friends have come and gone, made it through college and found a career. Despite it all, I would always come back to this game. I finally finished the story and epilogue and man, it may be a while until something like Red Dead 2 comes along again. The music, the characters, the world, the gun play, and above all, the story are absolutely fantastic, and if you're looking for a single player experience to get lost in, then this game would be it. 

Note: Do not buy this game for Red Dead Online. Rockstar has sadly abandoned online support for this game and it's riddled with cheaters and exploiters, which is unfortunate as Red Dead Online could have rivaled GTA Online.

I played this game the first time in the weeks immediately following the suicide of one of my close friends and coworkers. It was during the initial Covid-19 fuckery and I had so much time alone. All I could do was go to the gym and sit in my small apartment. I spent all my time on this game and it was a way for me to process my grief. When Arthur died, things really came to a head for me in real life and that caused me to reach out to my other friends that were grieving and start the healing process. 

I don't know, this game means a lot to me and is fun as hell with friends.

Wow, just wow, I am loving this game. The graphics are beyond pretty and it still maintains are good frame rate. I'm not even paying that much attention to the story but the little bits I do understand are well written. All the characters are down to earth and feel real, the interactions between each other feel real and are filled with humor. The shooting is fun and so is the hunting, horse riding too is really fun, which helps with the lack of fast travel, which is another thing I enjoy. Not being able to fast travel forces me to ride everywhere, really making encounters on the road stand out more. The one thing that this whole game can be summed up with is just one word, and that word is "realistic" but its realistic in all the right ways. I implore that if you have the money please get this game, it is one of if not the greatest games of all time.

A Riveting Adventure Marred by Tedious Journeys

Immersive landscapes bathed in stunning graphics welcome players into the world of Red Dead Redemption, where every blade of grass whispers tales of epic adventure. The combat mechanics, finely tuned and satisfying, offer players a dynamic engagement that keeps them on their toes.

However, beneath this visual splendor lies a narrative that, for some, may struggle to captivate. The story, akin to a slow-burning flame, meanders along, occasionally losing its grip on the player's attention. Its pacing, regrettably, tends to drag, leaving some yearning for a swifter tempo.

One of the game's glaring missteps lies in its travel mechanics. Mounted on horseback, players find themselves traversing vast distances to reach their objectives. While the landscapes beg to be explored, the elongated travel times can test the patience of even the most dedicated adventurers. Unlike its counterparts, the game lacks the option to expedite these journeys, leaving players stranded in a cycle of endless riding. Furthermore, the fast travel system, though present, feels burdened by excessive loading screens, detracting from the seamless immersion the game strives to achieve.

In conclusion, while Red Dead Redemption boasts breathtaking visuals and engaging combat, its narrative pacing and cumbersome travel mechanics may hinder the overall experience for some players. Aspiring adventurers should prepare themselves for a journey that, though rife with beauty and excitement, occasionally stumbles along the path to greatness.

Wow, what a beautiful game--it's a must-play. Absolutely worth the retail price and a no-brainer with the big discounts nowadays. It was a great game to make use of the new build with a 13900K and an RTX 4090 @4K. 

This is probably the most emotionally-invested I've ever been in a game. It's almost like a 2nd-life within the Wild Wild West. There's an interaction with almost everything and everyone. Great story and gorgeous scenery. I also really liked that in-game wealth DID NOT automatically make the game super easy.

My biggest complaint is the random game crashes--ERR GFX State and Directx12 errors. I've got the latest drivers and this is a relatively old game. Not sure why the crashes keep occurring. It's especially annoying when you're near the end of a mission/cutscene and you have the restart it ALL OVER AGAIN. Imagine something like this happening 3x on the same mission--I've spent 40 minutes on a simple mission because it bugged out during the tail end of a cutscene.

This is not a review about story or gameplay, everything there is to say has been said. My problem is that, NO, you cannot consistently play this SINGLE PLAYER GAME with no internet connection. It's absurd to me that a game like this, with a dedicated multiplayer launcher, still requires a proprietary launcher installation and a Rockstar account to play the singleplayer campaign. Yes, you need THREE programs installed on your computer to play this game. What part of the +100gb installation was not enough to accomplish that? Why do I need to provide you nearly all of my contact info including date of birth to even launch your game? After all that, you still have to play some fun menu minigames to get the game to launch offline if it even works at all. Things like this make me concerned for the longevity and future access to titles like this.

------ Spoiler Alert ------
I don't know who had this rather witless idea that Arthur Morgan should get and die from Tuberculosis. That makes absolutely no sense at all. First of all you can't get TB just from someone coughing in your face once. Less so being outside! You can even kiss someone with TB without getting it. You have to be exposed to it for a fairly long time. And if you really got TB back then it wasn't a death sentence. A lot of people had it for many years leading a more or less normal life. There was no cure, but hospitals, doctors and sanatoria specialized in TB and meds to treat the symptoms. People with TB also didn't die after just a short period of time being 36 years old like Arthur. There are so many illnesses and other ways for an outlaw to die, why in the world would you choose TB? Something that is less contagious than the common flu! 
I love this game! But I personally didn't feel very motivated to continue playing when I realized when/ why he's going to die. I started to feel sorry for Arthur and instead of going on adventures, doing side quest or buying things in game, I felt like Arthur needs to have a break constantly. And then - already knowing that Arthur's going to die in a few minutes after suffering and looking like a sack of raccoons for the whole last chapter  - why does his horse have to die, too? What did the poor horse ever do to you? 
Too much drama. Even for an outlaw. 
And then! Why would I want to continue playing the game as John Marston being surrounded by his boring wife and annoying son. Even Marston couldn't stand them for the longest time, why would I?

America, 1899.

Arthur Morgan and other henchmen of Dutch van der Linde are forced to go on the run. Their gang will participate in thefts, robberies and shootouts in the heart of America. They are closely followed by federal agents and the best bounty hunters in the country, and the gang itself is torn apart by internal contradictions. Arthur will have to choose what is more important to him: his own ideals or loyalty to the people who raised him.

I know everyone likes it, so I'm the odd one out, but this was just the most lacking game I've played in forever.  Maybe I just expected too much, given all the hype I've heard over the years, but slow reaction, poor controls, constant cutscenes, and just flat out long and boring story burned me out less than 4 hours into it (and that's with skipping some dialogue and hoping to get to play).  I wanted to like it, but I have to spend my playtime on games that are good right out of the gate, and this one just isn't.  With all the options out there, I'll take the one that isn't boring dialogue and fetch quests.  Having a story is great, but that doesn't make it a game.  TBH, I didn't even feel like the characters were all that believable or interesting.  It's probably just personal preference, but I don't even care to know how any of it turns out.

Red Dead Redemption 2 is a masterpiece that transcends gaming,immersing players in an awe-inspiring open world that feels more alive than ever. The attention to detail is staggering, from the breathtaking landscapes to the dynamic weather that adds a layer of realism rarely seen in games.

The storyline is an emotional rollercoaster, filled with memorable characters and unexpected twists that kept me glued to the screen. The level of character development is unparalleled, making Arthur Morgan's journey one for the ages.

The gameplay seamlessly blends action, exploration, and storytelling, providing a harmonious balance that kept me engaged for countless hours. Whether I was robbing trains, exploring the vast wilderness, or engaging in intense shootouts, every moment felt purposeful and exhilarating.

The visuals are nothing short of breathtaking, showcasing Rockstar's commitment to pushing the boundaries of gaming graphics. The attention to detail extends to the wildlife and NPCs, creating a living, breathing world that reacts dynamically to your actions.

Red Dead Online further extends the game's longevity, offering a robust multiplayer experience with diverse activities and missions. The community aspect adds an extra layer of enjoyment, turning the Wild West into a social playground.

In conclusion, Red Dead Redemption 2 is not just a game.it's a work of art that sets a new standard for open-world experiences. Every aspect, from the gripping narrative to the stunning visuals, contributes to an unforgettable journey that will resonate with players long after the credits roll. If you haven't experienced the magic of Red Dead Redemption 2, you're missing out on a gaming masterpiece that defines the industry's potential !

As someone who loves getting lost in games, Red Dead Redemption 2 blew me away. It's like stepping into a movie set in the Wild West, but you get to be the star!

The world they've created is incredible. You can explore vast landscapes, bustling towns, and everything in between. It feels so real, like you're actually there.

The story is what really hooked me. You play as Arthur Morgan, a tough guy with a heart of gold, on a journey to find redemption. Along the way, you meet a bunch of interesting characters, each with their own stories to tell.

The gameplay is a blast. Whether you're getting into gunfights, riding your horse through the countryside, or just chilling out by a campfire, there's always something fun to do.

What I love most is how alive the world feels. You can hunt animals, chat with strangers, and just soak in the atmosphere. It's like being in your own Western movie.

And if you're into playing with friends, there's Red Dead Online. It's like the single-player game, but you can team up with pals for adventures in the Wild West.

All in all, Red Dead Redemption 2 is an amazing game. It's got great characters, a gripping story, and endless fun. If you want to experience the Wild West like never before, this game is a must-play!

Red Dead Redemption 2 isn't just a game; it's a journey, a masterpiece of storytelling and immersion that transports players to the rugged beauty of the American frontier. Developed by Rockstar Games, this open-world epic sets you on the path of Arthur Morgan, an outlaw gunslinger navigating the dying days of the Wild West.

From its breathtaking landscapes to its richly detailed characters and gripping narrative, Red Dead Redemption 2 is a testament to the power of storytelling in video games. Whether you're exploring the vast wilderness, engaging in intense shootouts, or embarking on epic quests, every moment in the game feels like a cinematic experience.

With its unparalleled attention to detail, stunning visuals, and immersive gameplay, Red Dead Redemption 2 is a must-play for any fan of open-world adventure. So saddle up, partner, and prepare to embark on a journey that will stay with you long after the credits roll.

Be aware, as I am going to spoil this games entire story pretty much.

To be honest, this game is a total masterpiece. It's story provided me with so much fun throughout the free-roam and the story is incredible. It shocks me of how this doesn't have billions of good reviews. This game is so incredibly crafted and detailed, it is insane. On your guns you can customize everything and there is a decent crafting system.

What is the story like?
A prequel to the previous game in the saga, follows an unheard of character known as Arthur Morgan in his crew, led by Dutch Van Der Linde, on the run from the law after a shooting down in the quiet town of Blackwater, Arthur and his crew go on several heists, killings, journeys, and more crazy adventures. Arthur does many tasks for his gang before getting TB collecting debt from a sick man on a farm, eventually causing his death. After, you play as another member of the crew, John Marston, and wrap up the story killing Micah, the gangs rat.

Details?
Best I have ever seen. Water levels in barrels are actually a thing, so if you shoot above your last shot on a barrel water wont leak out. Guns have tons of customization, characters have routines, wildlife is realistic and mourns deaths of their packs, you can preform high detailed train robberies, your horse has incredible detail too! I mean, the horses balls even shrink in the cold. And that's not even close to all.

For kids?
No, unless they are mature enough to handle extreme and sexual topics. This game can get very gory and brutal, and there are multiple explicit scenes that kids shouldn't view. Definitely worse than GTA 5, however this game, you don't actually partake in any sexual acts, but the violence is worse.

I would 100% say you should buy this game. This game is so good I would buy it again. Hours of entertainment and tears to be shed. This game is worth an entire gaming console just to play it.

My only issue with this game is the online mode is tedious and boring, as there really isn't much fun to be had when your playing alone. Plus the microtransactions in online just isn't worth it at all. GTA 5's purchases are a little more worth it but I would put it simply as this: Don't waste too much time with online.

Most people complain over the rockstar games launcher too, and crashes, which I havent ever had a problem with, soo... 

So, what do I think in the end?

Online: Worth for some people, or if you have friends.
Story: Totally worth!

The reason why this game feels slow is because it's too realistic. Rockstar Games did such an awesome job on this masterpiece. Absolutely phenomenal game. They really are the "Rockstar" of video games. Bruh, this ain't AAA, this is quadruple A game right here lol. This is the best modern video game made even in 2024, other games don't even come close to this one and I feel bad for the shmucks who have not played RDR2.

Dude, the snow felt so real in this game, that when it snowed irl I got nostalgia of this game. And I USUALLY HATE WHEN IT SNOWS IRL. makes you feel like you should suck it up because our ancestors had it way rougher travelling in these harsh weathers. I also really love how interactive the dialogue is. You really feel like you're talking to characters cuz they don't say random dialogue that doesn't belong there, you know what I mean? This game wins in both the story aspect and the gameplay aspect! The only thing I didn't like and I wish the game had was the ability to fast travel properly.

I had thought Metal Gear Solid V: Phantom Pain was one of the best if not the best modern next-gen games I've played until I played this game.

Rockstar Games Launcher is kinda dumb though, if you try to run this game offline it works but eventually it stops working and you have to go online again (connected to internet) to be able to play the game. You would get a message like "Activation error". I don't know what the agenda is with game companies making it a requirement to be online to play even their single-player games. they wanna spy on us??? yeah, it's wack.

Another issue is the game is not so optimized to work with the Steam overlay (Shift+Tab). In the settings, if the graphics API is set to Vulkan, which is what it's set to by default, and you enable the steam overlay, you will get stuck lol. your steam overlay will be on your screen and you won't be able to get it off. But yeah. there's no way, at least I don't know any way to get out of it without restarting your game. You could try setting the Graphics API setting to > Direct x12 but that just makes the game crash more. because now there's another issue; on DX12 setting you can get the "out of memory" error on game startup. meaning game will crash. very annoying issue. I just never choose this setting ever. I stick to Vulkan and long as I don't bring up the Steam overlay, it's gucci.

Also wish they added a Quicksave command like Bethesda games have. Would really help on the path to attaining 100% completion since it is a HUGE game and you need to save often. the menu UI is slow. everything about this game is slow lol. it takes a while to get into the menu, save the game and then get out of it. A quicksave feature would've solved that problem.

When I first started playing the game I liked it but wasn't sure if it was masterpiece material. The missions ranged from okay to decently fun. The characters were likable and the dialogue was great. During chapter 2 and throughout a bit of chapter 3 I started to feel bored though. The story didn't feel like it was moving much, the gameplay was beginning to get a bit generic.

I took a break and came back, expecting this to be how I felt about GTA V's singleplayer. Overrated, but decent. I was wrong. The game really opened up for me midway through chapter 3 and into chapter 4. The story began to become a lot more compelling, rare for games these days. The missions became more challenging, I often found that I had to be a lot more careful and began to use consumables instead of just being able to blindly rush through with no danger to myself.

I was amazed with the details they put into the game. Characters would react to your hair length, if you were clean shaven, if you left camp for long periods. Subtle details would be changed in cutscenes or Dead Eye (bullet time) and Arthur's dialogue with others if you were at high or low honor (the moral system of the game). The game also has a lot of detailed side content and encounters, some of which you do have to go out of you way to find, but I find it incredible that they even bothered with some of the things they added, even small things like little pieces of dialogue that many people would not bother to listen to on their way to the next activity. 

The side content isn't forced, but it is fun to do. I wouldn't recommend going out of your way to grind every single legendary animal or grind money or whatever. I would do these things on occasion just to take a bit of a break from the main story. I got 63 hours out of it and I still had a fair amount of side encounters to see, animals to skin, but I did complete all side missions. If you don't like doing side stuff, I can see you getting about 30 hours out of it. That's just my estimate.

The story, hands down is the best I've seen in a game. If you already watched a playthrough or know the story, then I sadly am unsure if I would recommend the game to you. The story, for me, was the game. The story made me play the game for 5-6 hour sessions once I really got into it, which is rare because I normally can only go for 1-2 hour sessions. I wish I could erase my memory of the game and do it all again.

The game can be slow, the game IS slow, you are riding around on a horse in a vast land after all. If you want constant action, you're not gonna get it here.

That being said, this game did not deserve the Labor of Love reward. Red Dead Online has not received any updates for years. The people who voted this game Labor of Love have reading comprehension problems. It is a tragedy that this piece was abaondoned. There is a lot of wasted potential. But we did get something truly special with the singleplayer. It goes on sale for $20, and you're getting your money's worth with it.

The more I think about it, the more I can't think of anything else to say other than "what a waste."

You can see incredible work on both the graphics and environmental interactions. A great commitment to realism and the rendering of the characters on video. All this wasted in a game that has one of the worst missions ever. An almost total absence of a soundtrack which certainly doesn't help overcome the boredom of doing what seems like the hundredth quest like the previous ones.
I won't dwell on the strange physics of the game, especially with the carriages. It can also be fun and a breath of fresh air compared to the extreme boredom you have to endure.
The icing on the cake is that the story starts to get interesting between the fifth and sixth chapters and then the game ends. This leads you to think that the team knew very well how to make interesting missions and seriously develop characters, but they simply didn't give a damn for the rest of the game.

What a waste.

[h1] Red Dead Redemption 2: A Cinematic Masterpiece Hindered by Gameplay Woes [/h1]

Red Dead Redemption 2, developed by Rockstar Games, stands as a testament to the studio's commitment to crafting immersive narratives and visually stunning open-world environments. Released in 2018, the game received widespread acclaim for its rich storytelling, attention to detail, and breathtaking visuals. However, while the narrative and visuals deserve accolades, significant flaws in gameplay, character movement, world design, and mission execution ultimately hinder the overall gaming experience.

Story and Visuals (10/10):
Let's start with the positives. Red Dead Redemption 2 boasts an unparalleled narrative experience that rivals some of the best in the gaming industry. Set against the backdrop of the American Wild West, the game follows the exploits of Arthur Morgan, a member of the Van der Linde gang. The storytelling is masterfully executed, with well-developed characters, morally complex choices, and unexpected twists that keep players emotionally invested throughout.

Visually, Red Dead Redemption 2 is nothing short of breathtaking. The attention to detail in the game world is staggering, from the vast landscapes to the minutiae of everyday life. The lighting effects, weather dynamics, and character animations contribute to an immersive and visually stunning experience that sets a new standard for open-world games.

Gameplay Woes (4/10):
Despite its narrative and visual achievements, Red Dead Redemption 2 falters when it comes to gameplay. The controls feel clunky and unresponsive, especially during tense moments. The slow-paced movement of Arthur Morgan becomes a significant hindrance, making traversal feel like a tedious chore rather than an enjoyable aspect of exploration.

Combat mechanics, while realistic, lack the fluidity found in other action-adventure games. Gunfights can become frustrating due to the cover system's inconsistency and the sluggish aiming controls. The realism Rockstar aimed for often translates into a lack of responsiveness, causing player immersion to give way to frustration.

Empty World Design (5/10):
The vast open world of Red Dead Redemption 2, while visually stunning, is marred by its emptiness. While the wilderness and towns are meticulously crafted, the lack of meaningful activities in between makes exploration feel tedious. The world lacks the dynamic interactions and vibrant ecosystems seen in other open-world titles, leaving players yearning for more engaging encounters beyond the occasional wildlife sighting.

Lack of Fun in Missions (5/10):
The missions, a critical component of any narrative-driven game, suffer from a lack of variety and excitement. Many missions feel formulaic, involving a combination of riding to a location, engaging in a shootout, and riding back. The pacing can be slow and monotonous, with too much emphasis on realism at the expense of player enjoyment. The absence of compelling side quests or diversions further contributes to a sense of repetitiveness.

Conclusion (5/10 with Story):
In conclusion, Red Dead Redemption 2 is a game of stark contrasts. Its unparalleled storytelling and jaw-dropping visuals elevate it to the status of a cinematic masterpiece. However, the gameplay shortcomings, slow movement, empty world, and lack of mission variety prevent it from achieving gaming perfection. A rating of 5/10 seems fitting, with the caveat that those who value a captivating narrative and breathtaking visuals may find the overall experience to be worthwhile, despite the frustrating gameplay elements

I simply cannot fit all my emotions for this game in this review. I need at least 10 pages, I could honestly do a university work on this.
Arthur Morgan is on my top fictional characters of all time. I've felt joy, happiness, epicness, humbleness, rage but most of all an unending astronomical sadness for him. This is indeed a story about a man redeeming himself (if it's the high honour ending, but it's unanimously agreed that high honour is the canon ending), we start out a bad and unforgiving man, but once we start to realise our time is coming to an end, we change things around, and steer the pot for the best ending to a video game I have ever seen.
The story is a creation of gods, that's all you need to know.
In terms of graphics, this is prettier than 99% of games I played, and the amount of detail put into this is never ending. Each day I find something new I didn't know about.
There is no need to hesitate on buying this game, I got it in a discount at 17€, but man this would probably be the only game I'd pay 60€ for.
I have learned so many life lessons from this, also cried enough rivers to leave me with enough water for 5 years, and still after playing the game and seeing the ending 500 times, I still cry in every rewatch. Buy this game. Suffer with it. Learn from it. But most of all, enjoy it as much as I did.
A must play!

The first mistake i make today is that i uprgraded my vram into 2gb with amd driver. So it was 2gb vram and remain at 14 gb ram. I also ran msi afterburner, but unfortunately rdr2 only runs at around 6-10 fps which obviously unplayable. I noticed that the gpu temperature is only around 50, much lower than what i would have expect. After then, i tried to reset the settings into default, with only 512mb Vram and 16 gb ram. 

When i tried to open the rdr2 again with 1600x900 resolution and everything at lowest as possible, I get a steady fps around 30. The lowest would be 24 and the highest would be around 40. This game is very enjoyable since im a "newbie pc game player", even though my device is at the entry level, The experience still enjoyable

If you're looking for an immersive, story-driven experience that'll whisk you away to the Wild West, then Red Dead Redemption 2 on Steam is gold dust, partner. This ain't just any shoot 'em up; it's a tapestry woven with rich characters, stunning visuals, and a world teeming with life. Let me tell you why it's worth moseying on over:

[b]A Story Deeper Than A Canyon:[/b] As Arthur Morgan, an outlaw with a conscience, you'll ride alongside the notorious Van der Linde gang. But hold your horses! This ain't your typical black-and-white story. Red Dead Redemption 2 throws you headfirst into a moral tug-of-war, blurring the lines between good and bad, making you question everything you thought you knew about the Wild West. Buckle up for unexpected twists, gut-wrenching moments, and a climax that'll leave you saying, "Whoa, Nelly!"

[b]A World Alive with Every Detail:[/b] From the sun-drenched plains to the bustling saloons, Rockstar Games has crafted a living, breathing world that'll leave you speechless. Watch dust devils dance across the desert, spot deer grazing in meadows, and listen to the wind whistling through canyons. Even the smallest details, like mud caking on your boots or the clinking of spurs, add to the immersion. It's like stepping right into a dusty old Western film!

[b]More Than Just Shootouts:[/b] Sure, there's shootin' aplenty, but that's just the tip of the iceberg. Red Dead Redemption 2 lets you be a cowboy your own way. Want to be a gunslinger? Go for it! Prefer huntin' for pelts and trappin'? No problem! You can even become a gambler, a fisherman, or just ride around soaking up the scenery. The world is your oyster (or should I say, clam?).

[b]Don't Miss Out:[/b] This ain't just a game; it's an experience. Red Dead Redemption 2 is a love letter to the Wild West, filled with heart, grit, and enough adventure to fill your saddlebags. So saddle up, partner, and mosey on over to Steam. You won't regret it!

[b]P.P.S.[/b] Just a heads-up, this game is a real chonker. Make sure you have enough space on your hard drive! It's worth it, though. Trust me.

This review is posted on February 2024. 
This is my second playthrough. 

Wold design ---------------------------10/10
Music ----------------------------------10/10
Story ----------------------------------- 4/10
Progression and unlocks---------------  4/10
Gameplay------------------------------  3/10

World design is the strongest part of the game. Amazing views, effects, architecture, etc.
Music feels like it was composed by Morricone.
The story becomes boring after Saint Denis. 
The fact that you follow Dutch after so many bad choices, repetitive events and the same formula throughout the whole game is just bad. There is no rewarding turn of events, you just get tuberculosis and start dying while the game keeps the downfall of the main story so... yeah, that culminates on a very anticlimactic ending.
Controls are terrible, clunky and unresponsive. I died and facepalmed a lot of times because of this. 
Combat is also affected by the weird controls of your character, and it came to a point where I got overwhelmed by it. Instead of focusing on flanking or performing some fancy moves to engage the enemy, I just opted to attack on a somewhat conservative and cautious manner.
That combined with the not so compelling weapons unlocking and progression; the fact that many times you need to hit multiple times to neutralize an enemy, even with late game weapons and the overall unpredictability of the controls,  made combat kind of boring and frustrating. 
The speed limitations in specific areas, like camps, stores and random places are very frustrating and unnecessary.
The fact that the game restricts fast traveling a lot is another thing that prevents me from recommending it. A lot of times you ride to a very distant location to complete a mission, and after that you just end up in the middle of nowhere having to ride back to civilization. Even with auto ride it´s kind of annoying, they could have given you the option to go back like in some missions. 

So, would I recommend it? 
Well, this is a hard one for me. 
I think that despite all of it´s deep and game breaking flaws, this is a must play.

I don't know what else I can add to the thousands of reviews before mine that speak highly of this game, by this point I'm merely adding more icing to the cake by giving this game it's well deserved flowers. I am going on 40 years old, have witnessed the dawn of the home video game age from the glory days of bits and box tvs, have played every single genre there could possibly be, my steam account has a 5 digit friend code; and all this to emphasize just how LONG I've been around the video game era. Even through all that, and all the times I've changed my mind about what I thought would be the greatest game of all time: in 2024 I can whole-heartedly endorse Red Dead 2 as being one of the greatest games of all time.

Arthur Morgan is the friend we all wish we had. The guy who will ride with you to the very end. A little fuzzy around the edge of his character, but at the end of the day he is passionate about those he cares for the most, and in the end that's all that you could ever want out of a friend. His connection with his horse is the same as any boy with his machine today. The sheer number of things there is to do in this game outside of the main story is also mind boggling. Rockstar spent so much time working on this game and it shows in so many ways it's hard to describe it to be fair. Half the time you stumble upon something you weren't looking for, but you're glad you did. The gunplay is satisfying, the voice acting is Hollywood worthy, the graphics in 4k (if you can afford to have it run smoothly) is a sight to behold.

You would be doing yourself a huge disservice by looking over this game, and I cannot express that any more sincerely. I hope that this review will help convince someone to go on this journey as well so they too can witness a master class in what a video game could be.

Red Dead Redemption 2 is hands down one of the most incredible gaming experiences I've ever had. It's not just a game; it's a journey through the wild west that feels so real, you'll forget you're sitting at your computer. The world Rockstar has created is absolutely stunning, from the towering mountains to the bustling towns, every inch feels alive and full of adventure.

But what really sets this game apart is its characters and story. You'll laugh, you'll cry, and you'll feel like you're right there beside Arthur Morgan and the gang as they navigate through the trials and tribulations of life on the frontier. The attention to detail is mind-blowing, whether it's the way the sunlight filters through the trees or the subtle changes in your horse's behavior, it all adds up to create an experience that's truly immersive.

And let's not forget about the gameplay. Whether you're robbing a train, hunting for game, or just sitting around the campfire telling stories, there's never a dull moment in Red Dead Redemption 2. It's the kind of game that you can get lost in for hours on end, and every time you play, you'll discover something new.

In short, Red Dead Redemption 2 is a masterpiece. It's a game that reminds you why you fell in love with gaming in the first place, and it's an experience that will stay with you long after you've put down the controller. Do yourself a favor and saddle up for the adventure of a lifetime.

STEAM DECK USERS BEWARE. 
Game can run at a solid 40fps with some tweaking which is amazing for a handheld device, however Rockstar games launcher doesn't allow you to play this game offline at all.

If you plan on buying this to play whilst traveling or staying anywhere with no WiFi it won't work. 

The workaround I've found is connecting it to a mobile hotspot just for the start up and then disconnecting when you're in game. 

What a terrible feature for such a great game.

If I could get a refund for this game I would, while I absolutely loved every second of playing it. You may ask why?

Because of the dumb*** Rockstar launcher and their support - wanted to go for a second playthrough, somehow I am not authorized on their social club after launching the game. Found about 10 different workarounds on internet with people having this issue since game was released YEARS ago, none of them worked for me.

So I decided to contact their support - they do not have direct contact anywhere on their idiotic page, just faq which has average helpfullness rating of 5% so you can imagine its quality and how it helped me. 

Last solution seemed to be to send them email - got automatic response that I should create ticket through their support, for which there is NO WAY TO DO SO, and under my dashboard there I found my email with a question I sent them with a status set to resolved.

Go eat a **** Rockstar.

It has been a long time since i have found a really likeable protagonist in a game where i really liked! A very charismatic and strong one. Arthur claimed him self up the ladder of my favourite characters in games rapidly!
This game is amazing. High quality story content with good humor and great story telling just like always expected from Rockstar games. 

There is so much to do in this game you will lose your self mounting your (highly annoying) horse in the beautiful atmosphere.  Playing this with a 21:9 monitor was a blast and i am very happy for doing that, tho by having a higher 1440p resolution my PC was really sweating.  I have always had 30+ FPS so it didn't bother me much, tho i am used to play 144+ FPS... but oh well. a sacrifice to play on ultra settings ^^

I did have a few bugs here and there nothing major. But the horse...... oh boy don't get me started...... it is the only reason i was glad i finished my 100% run not having to ride him/her again xD

I did not touch the online mode, nor have any interest in doing so. I do hear that it is not that good. Full of hackers etc. It is nothing new. Same as GTA5 i guess ^^. 

If you get this get it for the story, for the HUGE and beautiful open world with plenty of activities, for a protagonist that you will really like (no spoilers) and If you have a lot of time to spend going from A to B with a some what slowish horse which  won't bother you than this game is for you.

I highly enjoyed and recommend this game.

10/10

A Story i could not get enough of!

The story is written so well and had me hooked, while there were sections I wasn't too fond of for the most part it was back to back entertaining. The characters are possibly some of the best in gaming when it comes to both writing and voice acting as it blew me away every time. 

The Setting of the Old West is fully realised in this game with each area being loaded with so much character and detail that makes the world that much more immersive. From the city of Saint Denis to the likes of Valentine, this game offers no shortage when it comes to locations that players can discover. 

Visually, it's still one of the best looking games that gaming as a whole has ever seen. However performance was not the greatest (especially in Guarma) as my PC would constantly crash due to my game being in either Vulkan or Direct X 12. It was especially hell due to it happening all the time in Guarma which i think is one of the weaker if not the weakest chapter in this game. Asides from that I didn't run into any bugs or glitches and when the game didn't crash on me, it ran really smooth. Art Direction is on point capturing the essence of the late 1800s and giving each area of the map its own feel while keeping the same tone throughout. 

Sound and Audio are just perfect with the soundtrack complimenting the game in its fantastic and unique way and the Audio matches every thing to a T. 

In terms of Gameplay, there is a lot to unpack. I would like to say that I really appreciate the detail that Rockstar have put into the realism, however i think it can work against the game as it becomes really tedious skinning the same animal or picking up each individual item laying around. I get that its to show off the realism but it can halt the experience and make it into a more annoying task. I think that combat is fine. While I do really enjoy using the Dead Eye system, the gun play is the same as what we got with GTA V except for a little more realistic movement with it. It works completely fine but I do with that Rockstar really changed it up or made it more interesting than what they had given us about 10 ish years ago. Asides from that, I really love the missions as each of them have pretty cool set pieces and keep the pace going. I really love the random encounters you can find in the world by simply wandering and discovering new people and can offer some of the best moments of this game. Finally, I really like the customisation that you can have with your character whether that be with your horse or your clothes or even the weapons that you carry. 

Overall, Red Dead Redemption 2 impressed me with a fantastic narrative that i could never get enough of. While i may had some nit picks with the gameplay and the performance wasn't the greatest at times, its such an unforgettable experience that will make you want more.

Plus, if you like side quests..... there is enough "other stuff" in this game to keep you entertained as well that has absolutely nothing to do with the main missions or story line (i.e. fishing, dinosaur fossil hunting? hunting, etc...). I recommend this game to all my friend gamers I know that haven't played it already!

Greatest single-player game of all time. When you put in the time to explore and enjoy the game instead of rushing through the missions, you'll find that this is one of the most detailed and vibrant worlds to interact with. An example I will use was when I was "Wanted: Dead or Alive" in Lemoyne territory and was riding my horse through the swampy bayou only to come up on checkpoint set up by the lawmen in the game. They were stopping carriages and horses alike to find me, only for myself to escape by using a side road that goes past them.

The only tip that I can give you, if you are new to this game, is to take your time and explore - as well as start the treasure hunting side missions early to give yourself a big leg up on not only your own equipment but the equipment that is at your camp that can be upgraded by the funds you bring in.

11 hours in, and Steam wants a review. OK, this game is freaking awesome, but even on a decent computer 
(Dell G16 7620, i7- 2700h, RTX 3060 6 Gig, 16 Gig DDR5, 1 TB SSD) this game is difficult to get dialed in. It took me about 5 hrs of Steam's "11 hrs" playtime fiddling with the insane number of options and bench testing and fiddling and bench testing again, etc, etc, etc.
But oh man was it worth it. Now that I have it running silky (50-90 fps) and pretty (most textures and lighting on ultra, most fog/particles/volumetrics on med, DLSS2 set to balanced) This might be the most no-shit amazing game I've ever dived into.
If you don't play it, it can only be because you hate yourself even more than your mom hates you.
Absolute masterpiece, and I haven't even finished the game yet

Red Dead Redemption II is a rich story about characters with umpteen-dimensional depth; I would say the game is worth it for the story alone, but it doesn't stop there!

The level of detail that exists within this game is baffling! I have had at least four random encounters per session that leave me either incredibly satisfied with myself or giggling like a drunk idiot. Or both.

If you're considering buying this game and aren't sure if the price is worth it (HOW ARE YOU NOT CONVINCED OF THIS???), then fret not, my friend! I bought this baby for a whopping twenty-something euros during the Black Friday discounts! A sweeter deal there never was!

This is one of the best games that I've ever played.

The story is absolutely amazing. It's well written and the voice acting to go along with those lines, are very well spoken and make the world of red dead 2 feel more real. It felt like the devs cared. I'm really impressed with what the writers have made together.

I know graphics will get better than this some day but for this game and it's art, it's world, it's absolutely stunning. Also, the amount of detail in the game is mind blowing. For example, I went into the water with my horse and only went in a certain amount a bit above my horses butt and there was a difference in colour for the horse and my legs being wet and above it being dry. There's a lot of nice little touches that amount to a lot for the entire experience.

The music is really good and fits the world. There are certain points in the game where you'll hear a song and honestly, to play the game and hear a song that is meant for a scene, like this is how the devs wanted it, is so nice. 

The gameplay is really easy and is just fun. It's repetitive but fun. You have a lot of tools at your disposal so it can never actually get too hard but the game does get difficult.

I ran this game on my really slim laptop that is several years old and has a nvidia 970m with 4 gb of vm, 16 gb ram. The game gave me ultra and high settings. The game ran amazingly well. I did not expect the game to even run to be quite honest but it did and went beyond my expectations. I would recommend getting a graphics card that is around 970 to play this game.

Honestly, the world of red dead 2 looks absolutely beautiful and seeing a deer in fog in the forest with the shadows and light is so amazing. Watching it run off cause I got too close. And I know I said this before but the amount of detail in the game is too much with the things that you can find. You need to experience it yourself.

There were a couple times that the game got buggy but for an open world game like this with the amount of detail that I was talking about before is understandable. I beat the game and there wasn't anything that ruined the experience. Maybe like twice I had to turn off the game and open it again because things got a little buggy. One other problem that I had is that you cannot play the game offline. Being forced to play a single player game online is horrible...

Anyways, a game like this doesn't come around often and I wasn't even sure if I was going to like a cowboy game but it was worth it. This is a must play. It's been over a decade since I've played rockstar games and if they continue to make red dead games with these writers then they have my money.

[h1] Why you should or should not play Red Dead Redemption 2 (Story and Online) [/h1]

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2915561463

[b] What is Red Dead Redemption? [/b]

Rdr2 is a open world (story or online) game. In the story mode you play as a interesting man called Arthur Morgan and you go around trying to help your gang while meeting new friends on the way and adventuring through the gorgeous open world. There is plenty of things you can do whether it is through the story mode or the online mode. Online is a little different then the story however, and you can meet other players in the game and talk to them through the open mic feature. There are many different types of enemies in the game (in online that can be other players). There is bounty hunting, horse taming, stealing, animal hunting and much more within this rich story line. This game is also based in 1899 if I remember correctly, so, no telephones have even been invented yet. 

[b] Initial Thoughts: [/b]

-"What a beautiful open world, wheres my horse I want my horse."
-"Can I kill this lady? WHOOPS, OH GOD, RUNN"
-"OH GOD OH NO WHY ME WHYY"

[b] Beginner Player Friendly?  [/b]

This game seems pretty beginner player ready, though online is not as friendly and a lot of murder does happen. The only thing is I never really understood the controls to well, they can be a bit confusing at first and you may need to check your keyboard or controller binds. Yes this game is controller compatible so that is always a nice addition to this game as well. There is a map that helps you navigate your way though if you want, you can just wing it and figure it out on the way.

[b] Game Play: [/b]

Once you get the hang of the controls you can kind of understand whats happening and how to work the game. There is loads of character customization and you can continue to edit your character throughout the game. In story mode though you cannot edit the character himself, you can only pick and choose what clothes you decide to wear on the character. This game has the option to have either a first person or third person view of your character, I favour the third person view a lot more then the first person because the first person view gives me motion sickness. They have many different features you can unlock throughout the game's story and you do the objectives of whichever NPC in order to get paid and progress further in the game. This goes for both online and the story mode. The story has more content then online does, however online has more player with player and PVP options that make it more interesting. Everyone plays this game differently, and its up to you how you want to make your adventure and what ending you will get. 

[b] Graphics: [/b]

This games graphics are absolutely gorgeous, though as of recently I have been noticing that a lot of them have been broken. My map, horse textures and skin textures have all been breaking. Which is probably because Rockstar has been working on other games as of recently. But I did notice a patch update so I hope that helps fix some of the problems. This game has some of the most realistic graphics and world textures I have ever seen, and it makes me appreciate them a lot even though sometimes they break. For some people I would recommend turning down the graphics as they can be super heavy on your gaming device. Sometimes my computer breaths like a air turbine even though I try to keep my graphics on medium. Thankfully my computer still doesn't lag and doesn't get too hot. There have been games that have pushed my PC further then this. 

[b] Community: [/b]

The community is a mic of, crazy people, role players, bounty hunters and toxic players. After a certain level however I have noticed that they aren't as intense. Some of the toxic players (which are not as common as they are in say, CSGO) do make very inappropriate and some times too far jokes. However the large majority of the community are pretty hilarious and I have met some absolutely AMAZING people on here. Some in which are going to read this review and tell me how cringe I am. The other people you have to look out for on this game are the modders, some are awesome. I am friends with some of them! As for others... They are extremely toxic and irritable. Though usually if you switch servers when you see flaming horse feet, you are pretty okay to avoid them all together. But again, the large majority of them are amazing people and are willing to help you out if you need and offer you some good laughs. 

[b] How long can you play? [/b]

The game's playability depends on how much you like it. I am only 5 hours into the story mode and I am still at the beginning of it, so if you are here for the story it is 1000% worth it and you can play it for hours on end. As for online, if you are only there for the content and not for the players then you will be able to have quite a while to play and sometimes it can be a bit slow paced. But if you are there to play with other people, you will end up like me and have quite a bit of time in the game because you want to hang out with your friends and be absolutely psychotic.

[b] My Opinion: [/b]

Overall I recommend this game if you enjoy story games (for the single player story mode option) or if you really enjoy hanging out with your friends and being forces of nature. I would also say if you enjoy just strolling around a beautiful world on horse back, this could be an enjoyable game for you.

[i] Any major edits that are made with this review will be added here: [/i]

*This review has been posted on both the online and the story mode versions of the game*

It arguably has one of the best and most engaging stories of any game ever. I have only been playing it on the steam deck. any time that I want to play a game where I am not at my desk and with my PC this on my steam deck is the go to, no questions asked. Graphics are beautiful. Story and emotion is plentiful. There are so few things I can physically fault it on it. There are fun and interesting, and importantly, a variety of different missions and side missions to complete. There always new things to discover and a range of different ways to play. My only issue, price. £59.99 is too steep, even if it is arguably the best game ever made. It makes it less accessible to everyone. I feel £49.99 may be justifiable, but pushing be too much still. If it is on sale and you've never played it, get it. You seriously don't know what you are missing until you experience it.

For people experiencing the error "Your Social Club Account is not entitled to RDR2":
1) create CPU load prior to starting game, not to reach 100%. Prime95 can do this for free.
2) start the game
3) disable the artificial CPU load generated once main menu is reached

Settings on Prime95 will vary based on your CPU. I have an i9 13900K and disable hyperthreading, test 16 out of 24 cores, and check "small FFT" to achieve 60-85% load.
