This is an amazing game, often ruined by some of the dumbest mechanics..
It's one of those cases where you actually start caring about the issues more, because they ruin an otherwise unique experience.

(This review is based on Story mode btw. I'm about ~70 hours in, still in Chapter 4, but have been meaning to write a review on this, especially after the torture the game subjected me to :D I have not played online mode at all.)

I'll try to not be overly negative though and give credit where credit is due... 
First off, Steam only gives me 2 choices... "recommend" or "not recommend" so it's putting me in a really difficult spot here.. while I was tempted to give this a thumbs down, I can't in good faith do so, because of the positives the game offers.

The real recommendation would be somewhere smack in the middle... or more like a "recommend with some caveats" because of the nature of the game having this overwhelming focus on immersion - which is awesome btw - the ridiculous amount of frustration this game can cause is beyond anything in similar games ever.. 
I would legit give this game the "Most frustrating game" award... at least in this type of genre.

[h3] The good: [/h3]
- the game engine is absolutely amazing and not only does it facilitate all of the features below, it also produces some of the best stock video game graphics I've seen and does so in a fairly performance friendly manner without any noticeable thread bottlenecks and the likes.
- It's probably the most immersive game ever made in this open-world category.. to the point where literally.. your character's hair and beard grows as time passes... 
- the world genuinely feels alive.. which is a pretty big one. Random encounters are seamlessly integrated, the forest isn't just a big empty collection of trees like in all other games... you have generic wildlife from toads to snakes, raccoons, rabbits, elks, deer, moose, wolves, cougars, panthers etc. etc.. basically you cannot take more than a couple of steps in the forests and fields without having some form of wildlife around you - all of which you can also hunt
- Pretty immersive hunting system.. various animals need to be killed with specific weapons for the best quality pelts and ingredients, otherwise if you have to shoot them multiple times or use the wrong weapons their quality degrades etc.
- While the story isn't something super special (nor does it need to be for a bunch of bandits), the missions are well put together and when the game lets you enjoy them, they're quite nice and very often have a charming comical overtone
- etc. etc... basically it's a really good game... and it would be an even better one if not for the other side of things ruining things.


[h3] The bad: [/h3]
- [b]The game has a horrible save system...[/b] the typical console "one-slot" system where it pretty much auto-saves everything as you go into that one auto-save slot. It's also over-eager in saving... basically if ANYTHING bad happened.. you're already screwed cuz it got saved.
I had an incident where I was going to either uninstall the game or restart from scratch... 

(TLDR: I was minding my own business and rode too close to some prisoner transport wagon and accidentally triggered them, making them shoot at me so I shot back, but suddenly became public enemy number one and they chased me to some town where both me and my horse were gunned down by a small army of law-enforcement people. I re-spawned.. and was informed that my ultimate edition bonus horse was dead and the game was already auto-saved at that point. Thankfully some googling told me I could repurchase the horse again, thou it took me several game restarts and the selling of that "replacement" horse I got before it re-appeared - so kinda buggy there.) 

You CAN make manual saves (which I discovered later as the game doesn't actually tell you and it's hidden under a menu called "Story" so not directly in the main menu as you would expect).
That process is just as annoying and tedious... every single menu screen fades through black for like a full second.. and the save option is like 3 menus deep... 
So to save... you press the menu button... select story... wait for the stupid screen to fade through black... select save game... wait for the animation again... pick a spot... wait again... confirm the overwrite / save.. back out of the save menu.... wait... back out of the story menu... wait.... and finally you can close the menu.. 

- [b]Loading is equally bad... [/b] saving the game doesn't actually save that moment.. it merely saves your "status".. when you load back up... the game plops you down somewhere in the vicinity where you were... doing something completely different and any random encounters or anything you were doing are gone... so you can completely forget about trying to explore various outcomes of a situation (which is pretty much a staple move of any RPG so if the clunky systems screw up the story for you, you can sort of try again)..

- [b]Character controls are very hit or miss... [/b] Your character has this "momentum" induced passive movement that was introduced in similar games quite a while back.. it makes you feel like you have input lag basically, but it can in certain situations allow for more organic movement.. 
This becomes quite horrible though when you're trying to actually loot items freely placed in the world (which is quite common), you'll find yourself often d*cking around for minutes trying to pick up something or open a drawer, your character simply doesn't want to do what you want.. 

- [b]The game has probably the worst law-enforcement system [/b] I have ever seen in any similar game (which is saying something...). It has all these cool systems like wearing a mask to hide your identity... except all of it is BS when it comes to the lawmen of RDR2... as they seem to possess psychic powers.. 
Brush up against somebody, trying to pass them... you're suddenly a wanted criminal.. and somehow every cop out there knows that it was Arthur freaking Morgan by name... so they'll send everyone after you and hunt you down :D  Ofc they ignore NPCs when YOU get robbed and kill you instead!
You can't even have fun generic fights with law enforcement... even if you murder every last witness... THEY KNOW... and your bounty just keeps going up, which you ofc will have to pay.
There were at least a dozen times where I ended up in massive shootouts with the police when I literally haven't done anything... either I looked at them the wrong way... or passed by them on a street... all of them ended up with me having to just reload a save in ultimate frustration. 
It's just puzzling how this ended up in the released game.. On the one hand you have all these super immersive systems that would be capable of seamlessly integrating proper immersive law enforcement... heck you even have a witness system.. and then on the other side you have this very dumbed down "police come endlessly until you die or run away with a massive bounty" that feels like it's running the same logic as some of the early DOS games.. 

- [b] Day / night cycle seems way too fast [/b], you barely wake up and drink your coffee (especially with that unnaturally slow movement speed limit in camp) and by the time you head out, it's getting dark...

- [b] Missions only tell you the challenges AFTER you finished.. [/b] like wtf.. I do the mission and the game is like.. "oh.. btw you were supposed to do this as a challenge..." doh..

- [b] They NEVER let you loot... [/b] This is one of the frustrating point too... every time you want to loot the people you killed during a mission... your companions either randomly die.. or the mission fails... or they just constantly yell at you to hurry.

Bottom line, there are too many small frustrating things that ruin immersion or just too many things that can go wrong unintentionally and then you have to deal with the frustrating save / load system on top of it.

"Long review": It took me 90 hours to finish this game, mostly because it has so much content and its open world feels so alive that I couldn't help but explore, and I explored as much as I could and I still haven't even cleared most of the map, not only the characters of the story feel alive, even the NPC's feel like they have their own daily life tasks like any real person. 

 The are tons of easter eggs and side missions, same can be said about the amount of events that happen around the game's world, I'm 100% convinced that after nearly 100 hours on this game, I still have not found most of the side events nor world events, because the world is so vast and huge that it takes me some time to get from one point to another, and in between my travels, there's always some side mission or event going on, even easter eggs. 

This game is a damn masterpiece and everyone knows that at this point, the graphics are absolutely amazing, my PC isn't that good but this game still looks amazing on mid-high graphic settings, its optimization is a 10/10 as well. Every point on this game including the story of course, are a masterpiece and you can see through everything and just makes you wonder the amount of hard work the people that were part of the development of this game had to put into this title. 

 The story of this game is fantastic, movie-like, the music gives me chills, the story is quite long but I'm not tired of it at all, even after finishing the story there's still a lot of things to do around, I enjoyed so much playing this game, I even took my time to read the damn books around the camp, they really make you understand characters such as Dutch or Hosea and it gives depth to their stories, and more importantly they motivated me to read a book, this game made me read Roadside Picnic and finish it, and I'm so ever more motivated to read a book a month, I know this sounds dramatic but bear in mind that for some people like me, games like this have a huge impact, including Arthur's journal, this game is just another prove that video games are much more important than we think.

 If you somehow see through this game and beyond its story, you can end up learning something important about Arthur's story and his redemption, you can even learn about some side characters and their stories, even some NPC's and all animals that you hunt, most people including me, don't read that, being honest, there's a lot of animals and I'm not counting the legendary ones, but that's just another proof that video games can also be much more than just mere entertainment, such as books and such as many movies, what a masterpiece, worth the price and worth your time, everyone knows that at this point.

 You definitely need to try RDR1 after finishing this game, its world feels alive even with all the restrictions of the hardware that we had during that era, I still recall watching the trailer of RDR1 when I was a kid, I was blown away by it when I tried it, don't look down on it, great game and a masterpiece too.

The reason Rockstar is my favorite game company is because they are consistent with their games. They drop one main game every 6 years and people talk about that game for more than a decade and they make more money than anyone else, just from that game. RDR2 is the perfect example of their consistency, because of its amount of details. I can watch a 3-hour long video showcasing the most insignificant details covering all parts of the map and I would be impressed every single time. And now with GTA 6's trailer and budget revealed, I can't even comprehend the technical advantages GTA 6 will have in 2025 considering what RDR2 did in 2018. Every second I spend on RDR2 my GTA 6 expectations grow larger and larger... How will they ever top this masterpiece? 

But... I still strongly believe that I will love RDR2 more than GTA 6, because of its deep story and characters. Every single gang member is so well written on their own with their own back stories and everything, and Arthur Morgan is no doubt the most well-written character in all of the cinema industry perhaps. Looking at GTA 6 I am scared of Rockstar, because they will once again change course of the video game industry, but what the Grand Theft Auto series will never give me is this goddamn hell of a story. This counts RDR1, and hopefully RDR3 in the future. 

For the online part... well... heard of GTA Online? Yeah, sorry but its just like that. Griefers and toxic randoms all over the place. I would just stick with singleplayer and do the hunting and all the other free roam stuff after you finish the game only, or preferably throughout the story.

After having nearly completed Red Dead Redemption 2 on the PS4 at launch, my journey into the PC version has felt like stepping into a familiar, yet profoundly enhanced world. The leap from console to PC isn't just a technical upgrade; it's a reinvigoration of an already beloved experience.

First and foremost, the game itself is an undeniable masterpiece. From the sprawling, breathtaking landscapes to the minutiae of life teeming within its ecosystems, RDR2 on PC elevates every aspect of its environment. The diversity of the ecosystems, ranging from snow-capped mountains to dense forests and arid deserts, is more alive and immersive thanks to the enhanced graphics. The world is vibrant, filled with people, animals, and countless random events that make every journey through it feel unique and exciting.

Arthur Morgan, the game's protagonist, is a testament to Rockstar's storytelling prowess. Spending hundreds of hours with Arthur, you come to know him not just as a character in a game, but as a real person you might encounter in real life. The depth of his personality, his struggles, and his growth throughout the story are portrayed with such nuance that it's impossible not to feel a deep connection to him.

The graphical improvements on PC are nothing short of spectacular. The attention to detail is astonishing, from the play of light through the trees to the intricate textures of the world. If you have the hardware to push high FPS, the game transforms into an even more stunning visual feast, significantly surpassing the console versions. The fluidity of motion, combined with the already exceptional art design, makes for an experience that is truly immersive.

While Red Dead Online has its merits, my focus—and recommendation—remains with the single-player campaign. The richness of the story, the depth of the world, and the connection with Arthur Morgan are where the heart of this game lies.

Red Dead Redemption 2 on PC is an exemplary case of how a game can transcend its original platform to deliver an experience that feels both familiar and refreshingly new. Whether you're revisiting the game or stepping into Arthur's boots for the first time, the PC version offers the definitive way to experience one of the greatest stories ever told in video gaming.

[h1]Red Dead Redemption 2 Review[/h1]

[h3]INTRODUCTION[/h3]
Rockstar Games have always been one of the best studios in the industry when it came to consistently releasing masterfully-crafted open world games, but [i]Red Dead Redemption 2[/i] is their best one to date. Red Dead Redemption 2 is an open world Western epic set during the tail end of the Wild West era, where outlaws and gunslingers were becoming a thing of the past and the modern industrial era had begun. There is a lot to talk about with this game that I feel this review wouldn't even be able to do it justice, be either way, here is my review of Red Dead Redemption 2.

[h3]A VAST & IMMERSIVE OPEN WORLD[/h3]
When I was a young kid, the first game to truly impress me with its open world was [i]The Elder Scrolls IV: Oblivion[/i]. Exploring a massive open world that not only looked realistic and immersive, but also one that was widely interactable, really blew me away and showed me just what video games could be capable of. Red Dead Redemption 2 is the first open world game I've played since Oblivion where the world is just as visually stunning and immersive as it is extremely detailed. This game is a true technical achievement that, even five years later, still feels leaps ahead of most games released in the current generation. Whether you're climbing to the top of a mountain overlooking the entire map in great detail, or seeing the impressive volumetric lighting cut through the clouds, will never not be a jaw-dropping sight to behold. The world of Red Dead Redemption 2 is so meticulously detailed that it's honestly quite difficult to really narrow it down to just a couple of examples to drive home just how detailed it really is.
Where there is a massive open world, there must also be a wide array of activities to do within that world. Red Dead Redemption 2 is filled with all sorts of activities whether it's hunting animals for food or pelts, playing some Poker and Blackjack, going out robbing stores and trains, or just simply getting lost and discovering the dozens of hidden secrets and easter eggs strewn throughout the world, full of environmental storytelling. Like with previous Rockstar titles, you can also do a wide array of Stranger Missions, each with their own storylines and characters, seperate from the main plot - Some of them wacky and over the top while others are more intimate and personal to Arthur. Whether it's partaking in the game's various activities or experiencing the Stranger Missions, Red Dead Redemption 2 has a lot to see and experience in the world. 

[h3]AN EPIC & ATMOSPHERIC SOUNDTRACK[/h3]
Just like with the first game, the original score for Red Dead Redemption 2 perfectly complements the open world and story missions. Woody Jackson, who also composed the score for the first game as well as [i]Grand Theft Auto V[/i], returns as the composer for Red Dead Redemption 2, with a much greater scope than before. You have your ambient tracks that playing during free roam, music for both Story missions and Stranger missions, and you have music that NPCs will perform such as playing instruments or singing songs around a campfire. The music that plays during Story/Stranger missions is fantastic, with almost every mission in the game having its own distinct score to accompany the action and lead-up to the action. The game's soundtrack also features vocal tracks from artists like D'Angelo, Daniel Lanois, and even Willie Nelson, that play during key moments in the story. With dozens of hours of music to complement the entire experience, Red Dead Redemption 2 has one of the biggest and most expansive soundtracks I've heard. 

[h3]AN UNFORGETTABLE STORY & PROTAGONIST[/h3]
The first Red Dead Redemption had a phenomenal story and an amazing protagonist, but Red Dead Redemption 2 easily tops the first game with what is both my favorite story and protagonist of all time in any piece of media. Arthur Morgan is such a well-written character who is phenomenally played by Roger Clark. Despite the game's title, Red Dead Redemtpion 2 is a prequel to the first game, showcasing the Van der Linde gang in it's final months, as the Wild West comes to an end and the modern world draws near. Even though the game's story depicts those events, the story of Red Dead Redemption 2 is primarily about Arthur Morgan, his journey and his development as a character throughout the story. Whether you choose to go the redemptive, honorbale route or the more dishonorbale one, Arthur Morgan's journey is an emotional and unforgettable one. 

[h3]CONCLUSION[/h3]
It goes without saying that Red Dead Redemption 2 is my favorite game of all time, but even without my own personal opinion, it's hard to deny that this game is a masterfully-crafted experience from beginning to end with an epic and emotional story, as well as being a technical achievement that outdoes even the most recent open world games. Red Dead Redemption 2 is Rockstar Games' masterpiece and is one that I wholeheartedly recommend playing.

After 700+ hours of RDR2 and coutless replays of the game I gotta give it a 10/10 best game. It is the GOAT imo. Great story that has a of heart felt interactions with loveable characters. Arthur Morgan is also one of the best video game characters of all time along side John Marston. They ended the 2 parts of the game beautifully with the epilogue concluding the game in a spectacular fashion leaving the fans satisfied, but also wanting more at the end and also to get them to play red dead 1. I've had my fair share of frustrations with the game when it came 100% it, but it was worth it. The online portion will not be included in this review bc that's a whole another part of the game that I think is to be made in it's own review.

So RDR2 story mode wise is spectacular. The intro was slow but felt needed to bring us some background of our characters and sets up the plot of the whole game. I loved all the gang characters even the side ones like Swanson, Pearson, Karen, Mary Beth, Tilly, Lenny, Uncle, and Hosea and many more. They did a splendid job really giving you time to spend time in this world and interact with gang if you chose to do so. My one complaint would just be the slow animations and menu screens that are delayed as you play the game. It's like super cool and immersive for the first couple of hours, but just starts getting annoying especially when you are trying to 100% the game. Anyways Rockstar did a splendid job with this and also thanks to the talented Roger Clark with his mo capture with Arthur Morgan and Rob Wiethoff with John Marston. It's an unforgettable journey that will pull at your heart strings and even make grown men cry in a video game which is okay. Overall would recommend this to all types of gamers and even if you don't like Western media. This game got me to love western media, and also due to my step dad loving it before he passed recently. This game kinda helped me through a lot and reminds me of him bc he loved westerns and american culture and history. It's a truly rare masterpiece in gaming and hopefully Rockstar does well with their next entry in the series. 10/10 GOAT game

This game managed to claim a very special place in my heart. I've always thought the idea of a prequel is silly due to the fact I already know how things will end for the characters involved. But if there's a way to tell a compelling story that takes place before the events of the original, this is it. Everything from the soundtrack to the smallest environmental details had me engulfed in this already beautiful story. If you're considering buying this game and find yourself unsure, I can tell you in no uncertain terms that you will truly fall in love with this game, and I urge you to give it a chance if you haven't already. There is so much more I want to say, but I believe this is something best experienced without words that couldn't possibly do it justice.

WARNING:
AS FOR NOW DO NOT BUY RDR 2 ESPECIALLY FOR THE ONLINE PLAY. IT'S DEAD/NO UPDATE CONTENT, NO PLANS/PROMISES FROM DEVS, AND LITTERED WITH CHEATERS. It literally can disconnect you from the server and force close your game/crashes your game.

But most of these time, modders will leave you alone and they're neutral modders. They do their own stuff like blinking or teleporting to their own destination, spawning animals or treasure chests for unsuspicious newbie to take. Sometimes you will encounter troller modder,or bad modder, where they teleport you somewhere, or drop tons of live dangerous animals on you, or simply blow you away to the sky and burn you. These trollers cannot be reported (you will crash to desktop), cannot be severed with (they can follow you even if you jump server). Just try to avoid them, contacting them, or harassing them.

RDR 2 Offline/Story is totally an awesome product. Reviews are below.

RED DEAD REDEMPTION 2 (Offline/Story Review):
Best game so far. Town is detailed, feel alive (each NPC can be interacted with, such as intimidated, say hello, troll them, etc), and packed with stories and characters here and there. You can always find something here and there. You can always make your own decision. Found a fellow in need? You can help them do what they need, or YOU CAN ROB THEM! Beat em to death, do whatever you want! With all the risk and moral penalties or rewards. If you help them, one day they can give you reward (i.e free gun from the store). if you kill someone, one day their wife will come and make a scene, etc.

The world engine/physics are amazing. Drag a crocodile on muddy ground? The muds around the crocodile will be formed accordingly. Running in snow as well. 

What i like
+Attention to detail, world details.
+Beautiful landscapes
+Characters
++Solid gameplay
+Good character movement
+Good combat

What I dislike
-Horse movement can be sluggish on tighter terrains
-Not optimized for lower PC! Very demanding.
-Shooting combat can be a bit hard

Conclusion:
A must have or play game even in normal price. Get the game especially for the single player, but don't hope too much for the online as it has cheater, most of them are neutral if not disturbed/provoked. Online updates has been drought so far.
Red Dead Redemption 2
GOOD GAME PLAY STORY
tb
good fun content

Fun but tedious.
Nakey Jakey's video seems to put it best.

Optimization
-didn't have much trouble playing the game. Sometimes has a weird glitch(?) that says it's running out of game memory? Only happened once though so nothing noticable.

Character creation/clothing 
-clothes could do a little better. Bandana could do better by simply adding a few color options. Masks could definitely do better (No Ned Kelly mask? Really?) But outside of wishing for more options there's nothing bad I can really say about it. (Ignoring John's segment because that lack of og hair sucks)

Graphics
-Looks great

Plot
-Great
-Except I question the existence of the honor system and the impact it has on the plot. The whole story seems to be geared towards the 'honorable' ending and gameplay so having the choice of pretending to be not is a bit weird. 

Gameplay
-The auto-animation thing that goes on is just plain annoying. The lack of control that suddenly takes over because the game doesn't want me to be too fast/slow is just simply annoying. Exhibit #1: the horse
-The horse: It's great - until auto-pilot drives me into a rock and throws me off, or I'm suddenly turning left when I'm pressing the w button, or when all my weapons are stowed into saddle and I have to re-arm myself again except the game wants me to use a rifle so one of my repeaters or shotguns are suddenly gone.
-I want to pick up that item next to the shotgun shells. But you can't really choose which items you pick up and you can't pick up the shells either because your inventory's full. Cue five minutes of carefully alligning your screen only to miss it by a few pixels.

-It's the one bad side of the game that's impossible to ignore; the constant inconveniences that keep on happening.
-eating/weight stats should either be easier to see (not pausing the game and using the menu) and should matter much more than it should or it shouldn't exist at all. It also should be much easier to gain weight (or at the very least it should be easier to see how consuming foods and such affect you)

-Open world gameplay is open world gameplay. It's definitely one of the better ones though.

After about 14 hours of game play, I'm about 20% through the story mode, which is compelling all on its own. The landscapes are as vast as the wildlife are active and unpredictable. Just put your headphones on and let this game transport you back to the 1890's. The towns and NPCs are very detailed and don't feel like an endless loop of redundancy. I haven't done many side quests or independent exploration yet (there is a lot of opportunity for that), but if I did, my story mode progress would be closer to 5-10%. If this game is a masterpiece, then I've only just picked up the paint brush. Regardless of your play style, this game offers rich game play for everyone.

this games story was amazing. the story was the best i have ever seen. and graphics are really nice.

but i have played this game so many times, i just don't see the magic anymore. and let me explain why. the missions almost never have choices. and when your given a choice, it rarely impacts the game outside of how that mission ends.

and the honor system for this game is terrible. the honor of an action is only explained after you commit the action. imagine going into a store, but the prices are only seen after you purchase products.

in all of my time playing RDR2 story i have never once completed a high honor play through, simply because of how hard, and not fun it is.

and this game also fails in some other sections. like the NPC's are all the same. same battle tactics, same animations, same weapon accuracy and fire rates. imagine 1 NPC Cloned to fill the role of every NPC. because after all, the NPC's only have different cloths, voice lines, and weapons.

and this is a western game but sadly much of the combat is either getting shot as you reload, or filling someone with lead just to kill them. for a western game, the combat and weapons aren't as good as you'd expect.

the missions in the online usually carry out the same way. and aren't to different from each other, making them not feel special.

and the online if plagued with hackers. no different than GTA5 hackers. the same old stuff with getting blown up randomly.

[ENGLISH]
“With the depth of gameplay and storyline as well as the overwhelming open world, just one article about Red Dead Redemption 2 is unfair to the game makers at Rockstar.” After 100 hours of playing this game, I completely agree with this statement.

Rockstar game is probably the one most dedicated developer I've ever seen. Almost all of their games make all of us surprised and amazed because how good have they take care their "childs" down to the smallest detail. That turns RDR2 into a blockbuster on par with the epic Hollywood movies of Marvel or DC, but instead of going to theaters for 2 hours, players spend more than 60 hours.
The open world of RDR2, meticulously designed by Rockstar, satisfies the elements I want in an open world game. From cities to natural scenes in the game such as forests, mountains, rivers, and swamps are designed perfectly Even each animal has its own characteristics and hunting method.
Gameplay is always the soul, the backbone of an entire game. In RDR2, this is an extremely big "plus" for me. Red Dead Remption 2 also has a vibrant "soul" with countless different activities. It feels like every person, every character, whether anonymous or having a strong influence on the plot... has its own life, its own journey going on where you can't see it.
All of these elements create a great game ready for gamers to immerse themselves in forever without being able to stop.

If i have to talk about Red Dead Redemption 2, one article will never be enough. This is a masterpiece of masterpieces, worthy of being one of the greatest games in the open world game series.
Finale Rate: 9.5/10

[French]
"Avec la profondeur du gameplay et de l'histoire ainsi que le monde ouvert écrasant, un seul article sur Red Dead Redemption 2 est injuste envers les créateurs de jeux chez Rockstar." Après 100 heures de jeu à ce jeu, je suis entièrement d'accord avec cette affirmation.

Le jeu Rockstar est probablement le développeur le plus dévoué que j'ai jamais vu. Presque tous leurs jeux nous surprennent et nous étonnent tous, car ils prennent soin de leurs "enfants" dans les moindres détails. Cela fait de RDR2 un blockbuster comparable aux films épiques hollywoodiens de Marvel ou DC, mais au lieu d'aller au cinéma pendant 2 heures, les joueurs y passent plus de 60 heures.
Le monde ouvert de RDR2, méticuleusement conçu par Rockstar, répond aux éléments que je souhaite dans un jeu en monde ouvert. Des villes aux scènes naturelles du jeu, telles que les forêts, les montagnes, les rivières et les marécages, sont parfaitement conçues. Même chaque animal a ses propres caractéristiques et méthodes de chasse.
Le gameplay est toujours l’âme, l’épine dorsale de tout un jeu. Dans RDR2, c'est un très gros "plus" pour moi. Red Dead Remption 2 possède également une « âme » vibrante avec d’innombrables activités différentes. On a l'impression que chaque personne, chaque personnage, qu'il soit anonyme ou qu'il ait une forte influence sur l'intrigue... a sa propre vie, son propre voyage qui se déroule là où on ne peut pas le voir.
Tous ces éléments créent un jeu formidable dans lequel les joueurs peuvent s'immerger pour toujours sans pouvoir s'arrêter.

Si je dois parler de Red Dead Redemption 2, un seul article ne suffira jamais. Il s’agit d’un chef-d’œuvre parmi les chefs-d’œuvre, digne d’être l’un des plus grands jeux de la série de jeux en monde ouvert.
Je donnerai ceci : 9,5/10

Lots of words ahead so to sum up, I can't recommend this piece of barely interactive media to anyone. Watch a movie instead, go outside, do something good, this "game" right here is a complete waste of time. 

I hate it. I wanted to at least finish the story, but that proved to be exceedingly difficult because the game doesn't want to be played, it plays itself. You can't even slightly deviate from the path pre-determined by the mission designers. Any disobedience of the great yellow marker will lead to immediate punishment(failing the mission). You literally can step in the wrong direction or climb the wrong fence and it's game over. On top of that the game always treats you like a complete imbecile. Go here, press that, hold this, follow the checklist, in order, follow this guy, too close, too far, don't run, don't walk, don't use this gun, use this gun, open this, collect this. Half of the time it just straight up takes over. If I had a penny every time the game took control of the character from me, I'd be like $60 more rich now. About the price of this garbage on the store. Ridiculous. On top of that, "immersion". This tries SO hard to be immersive. With all those physical stores, and animations of interacting with everything, and actually picking up stuff, and physics, and... everything. Like, clearly, a lot of research and hard work was put into faithfully recreating this wild west fantasy. But what's the point of all that "immersion" when it just doesn't work? This illusion they try so hard to build is easily shattered every an NPC decides to have a broken script and starts running around, screaming, because I didn't park the horse correctly or got off it a little earlier than when the game told me to stop. Or every time I have to wrestle with controls! Because we have immersion here, Arthur can't just turn when I tell him to turn, he has to realistically shift his whole body weight from one leg to the other and be sure, it takes a couple seconds, but he'll get there. And with this detailed locomotion system I just walk around the city and slam into an invisible wall/box. Because NPCs were just standing there and when their quest-giving stuff was done, the collision box wan't destroyed. Invisible collision boxes were part of the everyday life in the wild west, you see. And the mission structure too, it's almost always the same: meet a guy in one place, ride with him to the other place, shoot someone, ride back. Why can't we just meet there? Why we always have to shoot? Story is very questionable too. It's this central conflict of Arthur being an enforcer and adopted son to Dutch, who always says "We just need some money" or "One last hit and we're done". I get it, he's insasne, there'll never be enough, there's always a next last hit. But, look here, I didn't rob anyone outside of mandatory story mission, I didn't seek to make more money, but I have almost $10k in this worn leather satchel Arthur always carries around. Dutch, dude, you think this is not enough to get a fresh start? This is about 365 thousand dollars, adjusted for inflation. You sure that's not enough to get the whole gang to Tahiti or Australia or whatever? Of course not, the game doesn't consider this option. This game is not about options, it's about story and characters, it's a movie with a bit of interaction. 
And I wanted to finish the story, but I just can't, I had enough. Last drop was when I rode, again, from point A to point B, to start another story mission, and a bounty was on the way there. Alright, might as well catch the guy and get the bounty. Oh, he's actually camping with his wife and son? And he's not resisting. And he's like "I'm a changed man, but give me a moment to say goodbye". Alright, I'm not a monster, sure. So, he tells his son something and he's like "Let's go". I tie him up, start riding away, his wife is crying, his son is alone. I don't feel like bringing him in anymore. Take him off the horse, want to cut him free, but the same button for cutting the rope is the button for punching, for some reason. So when he's free he starts to fight me. Alright, I'm a little ticked off, but no biggie, I reload. Come to the same place, he says his goodbyes again, instead of tying him up... I can't do anything. I can't tell him I don't want to collect him(it's only $25 anyway, drop in a bucket of my ~10k). So I just stand there in silence. And he's like "let's go, unless you changed your mind". My man, I did! But I can't do anything! So I decided to just leave the scene slowly, see if he acknowledges it. As I ride away, I still see he's displayed as hostile... then he starts running away. His whole family is running away, from their camp, into the woods, across the river, screaming. I watch this highly immersive spectacle, and suddenly BAM, game over, "whatshisface has escaped", go reload a checkpoint. Dummy, bonehead, little baby, so-called free thinker, who do you think you are? Only do the things we tell you to do! 
And that moment, exemplifying most of everything that's wrong with this game, is when I decided I can't stomach any more of this. 
You can recommend this game to someone you want to suffer, I guess.

[h1][Review #24]
Red Dead Redemption 2[/h1]
[u]Single Player Review Only[/u]
This is no doubt one of the best games I have played. The story, gameplay, open world and enormous amounts of things you can do in this game is out of this world.

This game is a straight buy… to some extent.
I will detail most issues in the in depth section, but there are 2 main issues I want to cover here:
1.	Highly Unstable Port: 
Frequent crashing is something I had to deal with and it is very disappointing given that they had a year to fully flesh out the port, and that GTA V had a very solid port.

2.	Mission Replayability:
Gold medals are hell to get as always because half of the time in missions you are just walking around doing fuckall. It is just not fun. Why can’t we have the option to skip these segments so we can get to the fun stuff? Why can’t we just restart the mission instead of having to abandon it, wait for the game to load back to the checkpoint, then load the mission again? Why can’t we complete the objectives over multiple playthroughs like we could in GTA V? This shit is painful.

In short, this game is a masterpiece, albeit with some flaws including the most annoying mission replayability and the highly unstable PC port.

Rockstar did it again...beautiful graphics, captivating characters and well written story-telling. It takes a solid 3-4 hours for the story to pick up, but once you get to chapter 3 things get hectic and you really start to get really invested in the gang.

Do not go into this game thinking its GTA V with wild west and horses, it's not. This game is all about the story and characters. Often times the gameplay can be slow paced and some missions can take up to 15-20 minutes of just dialogue and horse back riding, but when the missions get intense they get really intense.

If I had one drawback about this game, it would be about the health, stamina and dead eye cores. Sometimes they can be a chore to manage because you need to run to stores to buy supplies every once and a while. This can sometimes be alleviated if you loot dead bodies after large encounters.

After finishing the story and epilogue, I can say without a doubt this is my favorite rockstar game to date. Go out and play a crown achievement of gaming history.

RDR2 is an incredible game, one of the best ever made period. I don't think I ever played a game with this level of immersion and detail. I got lost in everything I did, the stranger missions, the random encounters, the fauna and of course, the incredible story. Arthur's gotta be one of the, if not the best developed character in video game history. Like, oh my god, this game is HUGE.

However it is also the game that made me wonder how much level of realism we really need in videogames.
Everything you do is as real as life itself: eating, sleeping, bathing, god damn shaving. RDR2 presents you with all this menial tasks to be completed randomly, and it doesn't stop there. If you were thinking of living your outlaw fantasy easily, you were in the wrong my man. Movement and animations, and gameplay in general is predicated to be AS REAL AS it can possibly be. I can't tell how many times I got stabbed while trying to unholster my gun (which I swear is a nightmare, sometimes the input is so laggy that you can't take your gun out at all). I guess they were trying to make it, you know, just like in the wild west. You f*** around and find out for sure. This game really forces you to play under it's own rules; no more effing around. You wanna live in the west, well you gotta earn it. And once you do, man is this game fine.

Now, I can let slide those minor inconviniences, which are barely inconviniences at all, they are just the rules of the experience, because it's so perfect and unbelievably great, that this is definitively one of the most amazing games I've ever played. It's that simple. MUST PLAY.

I really wanted to like this game, I really did. Most of the main and supporting characters are interesting, the world you traverse is interesting, but the gameplay itself, sucks. Additionally, the controls on PC are incredibly rough, key placement/assignment directly conflicts with steam overlay, which means every single time you enter a firefight, you get the steam overlay because rockstar could not figure out a more appropriate key assignment. Getting jumped by random gangs in game is tough, because you have no warning, they only ever jump you when you have less than 10% health, and your weapons always reset when you get on your horse, meaning you never have your longarms available when you get jumped by rival gangs because the game says you can only carry a pistol anywhere in-game. I really wanted to love this game, but because of the indifference from the developers, 6/10, bad game design.

There is nothing I could say to describe how amazing the experience of playing this was, and it very quickly became my favorite game of all time. Well it's called the Game of the Year for a reason. Plus, winning multiple awards and nominations isn't any small feats. The realism and attention to detail is unreal. Who wouldn't love a western cowboy open-world game with guns and lasso, along with a rich story and numerous side characters and character development. 

Pros: Bullet holes that drains water, NPC interactions, NPC environment progress, Rag-doll physics, and much much more. Washing off blood and dirt off your horse by waddling in water, Skinning animals and sell parts, take on bounty roles or collection. Realism.

Cons: Online interactions. There is no chat box. A lot of hostile players that will shoot-on-sight and chase you down. Hard to earn money without doing dishonorable stuff. Shop items are expensive and most requires unlocking or reach a specific rank. Can't really buy any cheap wagons except if you're in roles and unlock hunting or collector wagon, but that's pretty much it.

Looking back on it after a few playthroughs, GTA V was kind of a bad game with many great elements. Characters have little to no enjoyability, the story is just weak, and its comedy falls flat with such a consistency that that its no better than the recent Saint's Row reboot, with the mild saving grace that it doesnt TRY to be funny every 5 seconds. However, the experience of driving around listening to a great soundtrack, upgrading your cars and weapons, and participating in a small variety of side jobs and the missions that don't dictate your every move was undeniable. Not to mention its MP, which was genuinely great until Rockstar bloated it with flying missile launching cars and other pay-to-grief mechanics.

Flip that coin over and you get RDR2, a great game with many lackluster to terrible elements; Characters are vivid and realistic, the story is one of the best in games, and its few moments of levity are not only well written, but also well earned. However, the experience of riding around on your horse listening to its scant but evocative string plucks of music is incredibly dull, interrupted only by the random acts of violence you can perform on passersby and the occasional O'Driscoll/Raider shootout. There are basically no missions where you aren't directed moment by moment to do a specific thing and upgrading your horses and weapons is much less impactful than desired. Not to mention it's MP, which never got to a good point before Rockstar again bloated it with pay-to-have-more-fun mechanics this time.

as an open world singleplayer game, RDR2 is still 100 percent worth the playthrough, no doubt, but im increasingly mad RDR1 hasn't been ported over yet.

Been playing RDO with friends (privately via a certain file you can download or something)
Anyways, RDO is fucking broken. It hasn't recieved any actual updates in literal years.
You WILL crash every 15-ish minutes on normal servers, there is no fun lategame activity you can do, you don't grind towards anything.
You will run the same 4 mission format types over and over and over to level up and get new weapons to use those weapons in the exact same missions.

Now you have roles (for premium currency which takes ~2 weeks to grind ingame if you want to be F2P)(1 week if you 2A your account you get 10 gold) which are semi interesting, but truthfully only the bountyhunter role is worth it, since that's the only one that gives you gold in addition to money, but as soon as you have the license you have full access to all the different bounties (legendary ones being the key ones I mean) Some are very interesting but almost impossible solo. (wolfman is for example annoying as shit, since wolves will 2 hit you regardless of hp it just measures time between hits I think, same with some missions in swamps, sometimes a random puma will spawn and kill you, which can be frustrating since if you're high enough rank with said bounty, you will have 0 team lives, and leggy bounties are on a 48 minute timer (invisible timer))

Overall, just if you want to play SP for the story, It's a definite recommend. I've heard nothing but good things and I've seen nothing but good things (that's a lie, game is clunky as fuck in movement and horses can be annoying as fuck by randomly falling, randomly not jumping, NPC's getting agressive over nothing, but that's just R* things, movement is the same as GTA5 just clunky) so it is extremely worth buying it, it's a great story game, gorgeous visuals, and fun to be a hunter.

For MP, don't. R* is a greedy shitholy company that is just out for your money. Look at sharkcards in GTA5.
I think they stopped updating RDO to 'force' people to go over to GTA5 and spend their money there. And when GTA6 is released they'll break GTA5 online to force the playerbase (cashcows) over to their new game.

[b] Red Dead Redemption 2... [/b] (SPOILERS... but who hasn't played it, watched it or at least heard about it?)
This game is a masterclass in story telling and world building, nearly as good as TLOU.

As you play through the story you find yourself coming across situations that end differently based solely off your actions.
One of the first actions involve a man who recognises you from Blackwater. You can let this man fall off a cliff to their death  to keep ensure his silence, or pull them up to save them. If they fall then you need not worry about him maybe telling the authority's where you're holed up but you will lose some honour. If you save the man then you gain some honour and he stays silent anyway... albeit under a threatening manner.

The story is built and effected by your choices. You can be rude to everyone you meet and kill without mercy. You can be kind to everyone you meet and show mercy when you can. The people in your gang/camp will notice and have different dialogues based solely off your choices.

 My first play through was spent helping the gang out with chores but showing no mercy to those outside the camp boundaries. In other words, outside the camp was no man's land. I let that man fall to his death to ensure his silence. After all, dead men tell no tales... right?
The further into the story you go, you will find moments where you're confronted with either a coyote or a buck.
The coyote symbolises your misdeeds while the buck symbolises your good deeds.
The character has a goodness in him that is buried deep below his loyalty to the leader of the gang, and his father figure, Dutch. 

Throughout the story I would do horrible things I thought I had to in order to keep the camp/gang safe. Through the story, a philosophical question comes into play. Do the ends justify the means? The end being to escape society's unstoppable thrust into the untamed world from where the gang came from. 

Dutch's goal goes from escaping society to getting back at society for all he's lost. He begins to spiral because every action he makes against society leads to something going horribly wrong and getting someone he cares for killed. Which makes him want to take more revenge against society. An endless loop.
Dutch, by definition, is insane. He goes from caring about his family to willing to sacrifice them for a feud with a rival gang and his thirst for revenge against society he thinks caused the death of his family members. 
He makes the same mistakes over and over again. Repeating outcomes that lessen the dream he once held of getting everyone out of the life. 

Arthur becomes the good man he was always meant to be by slowly coming to realise the man he once looked up to is going down a path that will get his family killed. Arthur admits that he hates dept collecting, all the needless killing and the death of gang members gets Arthur to question if the ends truly justify the means. What is the point of reaching paradise if all the people you care about are dead?

The story ends on a note that leaves you blubbering like a baby or fighting back tears as Arthur's journey comes to an end.
Based on how you played the game and the choices you made, you can get two endings where Arthur is remember fondly or he is remembered cruelly.
What I wouldn't give to play the main story for the first time.

Now for the world building...
B E A U T I F U L!
With my PC I have no choice but to play on low settings, but the game is still outstanding. 
The thick and soupy air in the swamp, the shiver down your spine in the snowy mountains, the fresh air and vibrancy of the woods. 
The towns make you feel like you're really in the 1890's The pubs, stores, hotel, stable, the people, the clothing, the general attitude of everyone you talk to. The atmosphere is truly astonishing.
The graphics are still top notch even to today's standards. 
The fluidity of the animations and movements makes everything flow smoothly and precisely.

Rockstar know's how to make a game look good and more importantly know how to emotionally involve you into the world and characters. The voice actors deserve the praise they receive based off their stellar performances. 
Every argument, every heartfelt talk, every gut wrenching moment makes you feel like you ARE the main character.
The dialogue doesn't feel clunky or forced like some games *Cough cough* MWIII *Cough* Excuse me, sorry. That was strange.
It feels natural and real. It draws you in. 

Would I suggest this game? YES!!!!
Even if you've watched a play through. When you get to make the hard choices, when you get to decide mercy or death, when you decide how the game ends it feels much more rewarding. 
At the end you'll feel remorse for your less than honourable actions and wish you could go back to change some.
Or you can also be happy knowing you died being selfish, a dealer of death and have no remorse or regret. 

That's the beauty of this game. I believe the actions you choose says a lot about your own character. 
Will you take the risk and spare the man hanging off the cliff?
Will you refuse mercy and ensure his silence?
The choice is truly yours to make.

They really did whatever they could to diminish the aspects of this game that are fun. They have long missions that require you to "walk" through what should be a cut scene. They also spend a lot of time trying to preach and force some sort of moral lesson on you, meanwhile you need to complete the missions by shooting everyone in the head, or else you don't get a gold medal. I don't give a rats a** for your morality lessons, let me slaughter everything and stop trying to make me feel bad about it. This is a video game about being an outlaw, not a Sunday school lesson.

[h1] [b] OVERVIEW on RDR2 [/b] [/h1]


Red Dead Redemption 2, prequel to Red Dead Redemption 1, is a visually stunning game that follows the heartbreaking story of the outlaw Arthur Morgan and his journey to redemption.

Red Dead Redemption remains many people's favourite game; even after the game has been completed, still having many weapons, animals, clothes and overall "customisables" to unlock. Additionally, the game keeps audiences interested with many side missions, as well as constantly immersing the viewer in the story that is [spoiler] the downfall and destruction of the Van Der Linde gang. [/spoiler] 

In addition to the story, the game centres itself around various characters; all with interesting backstories and subtle but effective character development as the game progresses, e.g; [spoiler] Arthur Morgan, the main protagonist, (depending on your honour level), goes from a sarcastic outlaw to a selfless hero - chapter 1 through to chapter 6 and Dutch Van Der Linde transforming from a charismatic leader in chapter 1 to a ruthless and psychotic murderer in chapter 6 [/spoiler]. These characters are incredibly well written, allowing audiences to sympathise with said character and feel strongly attached to them - for example, (to my knowledge), every time a character dies in Red Dead Redemption, the audience will feel upset as they have been attached to said character over the course of their playtime (several hours).

The gameplay is incredibly simple - most of the game just having to shoot those shooting at you, but still having unique features: The "Deadeye" feature allows players to draw their weapon at a swift speed, allowing the player to fire multiple accurate shots in a short span of time. Additionally, the game includes an underused "drawing" system, similar to "Deadeye", allowing players to quickly equip their weapon and fire a shot into their opposition.

Overall, Red Dead Redemption 2 is a highly adored video game that has a strongly immersive story, simple gameplay mechanics and an addictive abundance of unlockables. I implore that you should play Red Dead Redemption 2.

[h3] TL;DR: [/h3]


Red Dead Redemption 2 is a perfect shooter and story game that I strongly recommend it to everyone.

Rewriting my review now that I've had a chance to play the game. I'll keep it short.

This game is absolutely amazing. You do NOT need to have played the previous game to understand and enjoy this one, though it's always good to look up a synopsis of what happened in RDR1 or play the game itself. Either way, jump in and enjoy this masterpiece for what it is.

I'd recommend doing all side quests as they appear because you may miss out on some when you move from chapter to chapter. Also avoid purchasing weapons and outfits in the early game - you'll get plenty as you progress through the game. Now go and enjoy the game, it'll be well worth your time!


Note: if you run into issues with the game not launching, here is what worked for me:

1) I deleted all my profile files both under the RDR2 and Social Club folders.
2) I ran Steam as administrator.

Title: Red Dead Redemption 2  A Wild West [b]Masterpiece[/b]

Rating: ★★★★★

Red Dead Redemption 2 is not just a game; it's an emotional journey that immerses you in the raw beauty and harsh realities of the Wild West. From the heartwrenching narrative to the breathtaking visuals, this [b]masterpiece[/b] sets a new standard for openworld adventures.

Pros:

Immersive Storytelling: Brace yourself for an emotional rollercoaster. The narrative unfolds like a gripping novel, weaving the tale of Arthur Morgan and the Van der Linde gang. Each character is a [b]masterpiece[/b], with their own compelling stories that will leave you emotionally invested.

 Stunning Visuals and Attention to Detail: Prepare to be awestruck by the sheer beauty of Red Dead Redemption 2. The landscapes are not just picturesque; they're living canvases that change with the dynamic weather. Every nook and cranny is filled with meticulous detail, creating an immersive experience like no other.

 Vast and Dynamic Open World: Step into a world that [b]breathes[/b]. The vastness is staggering, but it's the depth that truly mesmerizes. From lively towns to serene landscapes, the dynamic ecosystem and realistic animal behavior make every moment feel alive, contributing to a truly immersive experience.

 Realistic Characters and Acting: The characters come to life with impeccable animations and outstanding voice acting. Roger Clark's portrayal of Arthur Morgan is nothing short of a [b]masterpiece[/b], adding emotional depth and resonance to an already compelling narrative.

 Robust Gameplay Mechanics: Engage in a perfect dance of realism and fun. Whether you're in the midst of intense gunplay, riding your horse across the vast landscapes, or engaging in intricate activities like hunting and fishing, every gameplay element feels polished and wellexecuted.

Cons:

 Steep Learning Curve: Be ready to invest time in mastering the game's intricacies. The learning curve can be steep, especially for those new to openworld experiences. However, the effort pays off for those seeking a truly immersive adventure.

 Pacing Issues: At times, the deliberate pace of the game may feel slow, particularly in the early chapters. But, this intentional choice aims to immerse players in the world, and for those willing to invest, the payoff is [b]immense[/b].

Conclusion:

Red Dead Redemption 2 transcends the realm of gaming; it's a testament to the emotional power of interactive storytelling. Despite a few challenges, the game's strengths far outweigh any shortcomings. If you're ready to embark on an [b]emotional journey[/b], filled with rich narratives, expansive open worlds, and attention to detail, this game is an absolute mustplay. Highly recommended for those seeking an [b]unforgettable[/b], [b]emotional[/b] adventure in the heart of the Wild West.

Red Dead Redemption 2 easily one of the best video games ever made period. Where to start

The story is riveting and captivating.  You are immediately absorbed into the world of Arthur Morgan and his gang ( literally his gang) and as the story progresses you quickly learn your place in the world of the Wild West. Probably my favorite aspects of the main story is 1. The moral ambiguity of your position, a bandit who also takes care of his own, faced with multiple instances of having to choose right or wrong, the better or the worse option you can feel like you mold Arthur in a direction you choose. 2. The variety of missions, from Outlaw to Deputy to Outlaw again. Missions done in secret, breaking down the door, raiding a plantation, raiding a graveyard, working with the scum of the west in the hills or the crooked politicians in Saint Denis. This game has it ALLL
Graphics are STILL to this day some of the best you will ever see in any video game 
And what makes it even better is Rockstar found the perfect way to make the world come alive, not just look good. Travel down the road to find people in distress or perhaps theyll pay you even, get stopped by 3 men at gun point? It all happens, the animals flee or attack depending. The weather changes and the reflection on your clothes... it all matters, Even if you shoot a barrel 3 times , one at the top, one in the middle and one in the botttom... youll see the water levels reduce as the water flows out. The details are insane.

I cannot recommend this game enough. One where you must immerse and invest yourself into Arthur Morgans world
It would only be better if you could shoot Dutch in the face in chapter 1.

Red Dead Redemption 2: A Breathtaking Journey into the Heart of the Wild West

Red Dead Redemption stands as a shining example of narrative excellence within the realm of video games, weaving a breathtaking, amazing, and heartfelt story set against the vast, untamed landscapes of the American Wild West. Developed by Rockstar Games, this open-world masterpiece not only captivates players with its stunning visuals and dynamic gameplay but also immerses them in a profound and emotionally charged narrative that transcends the boundaries of the gaming medium.

From the outset, Red Dead Redemption draws players into the compelling life of John Marston, a former outlaw seeking redemption in a world that is rapidly changing. The game's narrative unfolds with cinematic precision, revealing a rich tapestry of characters, each with their own dreams, struggles, and moral dilemmas. As players traverse the expansive frontier, encountering a diverse cast of personalities, they become engrossed in the intricacies of their stories, forging deep connections with the characters and the world they inhabit.

The Wild West setting serves as more than just a backdrop; it is a character in itself, shaping the narrative and influencing the actions of the protagonists. The attention to detail is unparalleled, with vast, sweeping landscapes that shift seamlessly from arid deserts to snowy mountains. The immersive world of Red Dead Redemption is teeming with life, from the bustling towns to the serene beauty of the wilderness, creating an environment that feels alive and authentic.

What sets Red Dead Redemption apart is its ability to evoke genuine emotion from players. The narrative is not a mere series of missions but a heartfelt exploration of themes such as love, loss, and the inexorable passage of time. John Marston's quest for redemption is a poignant and deeply human journey that resonates on a visceral level. The game's writers masterfully blend action-packed sequences with moments of quiet reflection, allowing players to connect with the characters on a profound emotional level.

The voice acting and character animations further enhance the storytelling, bringing the cast to life with a level of realism that is nothing short of extraordinary. Whether it's the grizzled wisdom of Dutch van der Linde or the fiery spirit of Bonnie MacFarlane, every character feels like a fully realized individual with their own hopes, fears, and motivations.

In conclusion, Red Dead Redemption stands as a testament to the potential of video games as a storytelling medium. It combines breathtaking visuals, engaging gameplay, and a narrative that is as compelling as any found in literature or film. Through its carefully crafted characters, evocative setting, and emotional depth, the game transcends the boundaries of entertainment, offering players an immersive and unforgettable journey into the heart of the Wild West. Red Dead Redemption is more than a game; it is a work of art that leaves an indelible mark on the hearts and minds of those who experience its captivating tale.

This game. It hits different. There is so much to do, so much to learn. The story tells a wonderful outlaw redemption. You will feel and go through an array of emotions. On computer (as of writing this) I have about 245 hours. On PS4 I have over 2000. Even so, I still find things that I've never seen before. No matter how many times I play the main story, it never gets old. This is one of those games that are actually worth buying. This is not just a "Cowboy GTA 5." This is something completely different. Hell, I've played both GTA 5 and RDR2 completely, RDR2 definitely beats in nearly all ways possible. Although I'm unsure of what GTA 6 has in store for us, RDR2 will be difficult to surpass in genuine fun and storytelling. You can do just about everything in the game. Go hunting, have fun with gang members, go rob a house, or a store, possibly go start a massacre in a town, find new horses, study and skin all the animals in the game, just go explore and listen to the music, find all the plants and herbs, find all the guns, visit all the strangers, and so much more. The list is massive. This game is definitely currently the best game ever created. It will be hard to trump this game... 

If you've made it this far, I thank you for reading my review. If you don't own this game, I recommend it a thousand times over. You will not regret it.

Red Dead Redemption 2 (RDR2) is nothing short of a masterpiece, a magnum opus in the world of gaming that takes players on an unforgettable journey through the rugged landscapes of the American heartland. Developed by Rockstar Games, the same studio behind the Grand Theft Auto series, RDR2 elevates the standards of open-world gaming to unprecedented heights. 

   Graphics 10/10
  From the moment you set foot in the sprawling open world, it's impossible not to be captivated by the breathtaking graphics and attention to detail. The game's visuals are a testament to the advancements in gaming technology, delivering a level of realism that immerses players in the vast and dynamic landscapes. The changing weather, day-night cycles, and realistic physics contribute to an unparalleled sense of immersion.

    Characters And Story Mode 10/10

  RDR2's narrative is a triumph in storytelling, creating a compelling and emotionally charged experience. The protagonist, Arthur Morgan, is a deeply nuanced character whose journey is shaped by the choices players make. The supporting cast is equally well-crafted, each with their own stories and motivations. The intricate relationships and evolving dynamics within the Van der Linde gang add layers of complexity to the narrative, making every interaction meaningful. The game's pacing is deliberate, allowing players to savor the unfolding drama. Rockstar has masterfully blended action, drama, and introspection, creating a narrative that explores themes of loyalty, morality, and the consequences of one's actions. RDR2's story is a triumph that transcends the gaming medium, comparable to the best works in literature and film.


   Open World Quality And Interactions 9/10

     The open-world design of RDR2 is a marvel. The vast landscapes, ranging from snow-covered mountains to swamps teeming with life, invite exploration. The attention to detail extends beyond the visual aspect, with a living, breathing ecosystem. Wildlife behaves realistically, and the world reacts to the player's actions.


  Gameplay Mechanics / Realism / Immersion 8/10

 The gameplay mechanics of RDR2 are both intuitive and complex. From gunplay to horseback riding, every action feels grounded and authentic. The attention to realism is evident in the need to maintain Arthur's health, stamina, and Dead Eye core. This adds a layer of strategy, as players must manage resources and make choices that impact Arthur's well-being. The attention to detail extends to the interactions with the environment. Whether it's the meticulous reloading of firearms or the realistic portrayal of horse bonding, every aspect of the game is designed with a commitment to authenticity. The realism enhances the overall immersion, making every moment feel consequential.


 Technical Aspects and Performance 7/10

 RDR2 is a technical marvel, but it demands robust hardware to unleash its full potential. The PC version, in particular, shines with its enhanced graphics options and customization. However, the game's performance can be demanding on lower-end systems, requiring players to strike a balance between visual fidelity and smooth gameplay. Despite occasional technical hiccups, such as minor glitches or frame rate drops, the overall experience is polished. The attention to detail, dynamic lighting, and realistic animations showcase Rockstar's commitment to delivering a visually stunning and technically impressive game.

 Conclusion/ Overall |  10/10
Red Dead Redemption 2 is more than a game; it's an immersive, emotional, and thought-provoking experience. Rockstar Games has set a new standard for open-world storytelling, creating a world that feels alive and evolving. From the stunning visuals to the deep narrative and engaging gameplay, RDR2 is a triumph on multiple fronts. The game's impact extends beyond the gaming community, resonating with those who appreciate storytelling as an art form. It's a testament to the potential of video games as a medium for delivering compelling narratives and meaningful experiences. While the game may not be for everyone due to its deliberate pacing and commitment to realism, those who invest the time will find themselves rewarded with one of the most memorable gaming experiences of this generation. Red Dead Redemption 2 stands as a shining example of what is possible in the world of interactive entertainment, and its influence will undoubtedly be felt for years to come. In the end, Red Dead Redemption 2 is not just a game; it's a journey into the heartland, a testament to the boundless potential of storytelling in the digital age. If you're seeking an unforgettable adventure that transcends the traditional boundaries of gaming, saddle up and embark on the epic odyssey that is Red Dead Redemption 2.
